item.title: Estelle Getty is dead
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
I have just learned some very troubling news...
The Associated Press LOS ANGELES — Estelle Getty’s son says the 84-year-old actress has died
I will write more later. Right now I want to curl up with my favorite season of "The Golden Girls" and Netflix "Mannequin." She will be missed!

item.title: Leaving Las Visalia
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Three years ago, I began a new chapter in my life when my college experience ended. On Aug. 1, 2005, I left Athens, Ga., to live with my mother in Ohio. It was a difficult change to make but it eventually led me to my new home, Visalia, Calif., where I began my career as a journalist, serving as copy editor at the Visalia Times-Delta newspaper. After over a year of work on the copy desk, I began to show an interest in multimedia, prompting my editors to create for me the position of multimedia reporter — a position which afforded me the opportunity to produce video content for our newspaper's Web site. I have been in that position for over a year now, leading me to my next big change. It's August 1 again and I'm going home — again.
It's kind of a rush, to say the least. I find it rather ironic that this point of the year beckons me back to Ohio. Though it is true that I am moving to Columbia, Mo., to attend graduate school at the University of Missouri-Columbia, I am traveling to Ohio to pick up my mother, who will help me move into my apartment in Columbia. The journey begins at 5 p.m. August 1, when my employment with Gannett ends. I will drive to Las Vegas to see my college friends Padmini and Braniff. I will spend Saturday with them before embarking early Sunday morning for however far I can drive down Interstate 70 in one day. On Monday I assume I'll be in Kansas, on my way to Ohio. I'll drive past Columbia and into St. Louis, where I will pick up my sister. Together we will go to Brookville, Ohio, where we will rest and wait for my mother to finish her night shift at the hospital. Tuesday afternoon, the three of us will head back to Columbia, get a hotel room and rest before moving the things I packed this past weekend into my new apartment.
So, yeah, that's the plan. It's really ending. My time in California has come to an end. More experiences in this wonderful state are to come, I am certain, but this detour is necessary. Graduate school, the next chapter in my life, will afford me many opportunities that Gannett and the Times-Delta will not. I will have the opportunity to develop my new media skills beyond the editing prowess and content management understanding I've mastered at the Times-Delta. My dedication to coding and Web design will be re-invested and invigorated — at least I hope. I aim to be finishing up an internship at a major media or new media corporation or Web site by this time next year. I will be cultivating the connections necessary to acheive the career goals I have set for myself in the next 5 years. Hopefully, by the end of that time, I will have re-located to my dream location — Washington D.C. — covering politics and employing my skills for a company that values my skills, intelligence and experience.
That's the dream. And it all starts today, August 1. I have been waiting for this day long before I knew it would come this day, this time, this year. I always knew I would be leaving the Times-Delta. I knew that the Central Valley was not the place for me. I love the mountains, I love the Sierra. I will miss Yosemite. I will miss the Central Coast. Los Angeles will alas quake without me. And I will continue to curse San Francisco, who not only litters my car window with parking tickets but exceeds in thwarting my flirtations with alternative transportation (translation: My bike was stolen last month on Market Street in San Francisco). But all of this is not enough to make me stay. I must move on. Finishing graduate school is something I have known I must do. Now the time has come.
As for my blog, big changes are coming. More on that when I make it a little further from California.
Thanks for reading. See you on the other side.

item.title: New digs, new site
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: I am happily settled in Columbia, Mo., and my move couldn't have gone better. My car, which has driven all across California several times as well as all the way from Ohio, arrived safe in sound in the same state from which I embarked nearly three years ago. The move was kind of hectic but after some TLC, my new apartment is positively fabulous. I'm getting oriented and trying to find my footing here academically and professionally, but for the most part things are going well. I should be really excited, but to be honest, I feel so subdued. It's just me, after all. I'm just waiting for the fun to begin. One thing I've been working on for several weeks is a new blog. I'm moving from MovableType to WordPress and I'm launching this week. I plan on bloggin a lot more (I know, you've heard that before), but this time I mean it. I have more time, I think, and I am anxious to sharpen my blogging prowess. I want to become a more respected voice on politics, news, film and all the crazy junk I write about. And I want to grow in a lot of other different ways too. We'll see, I guess. Anyways, thanks for reading and hopefully you'll be reading more and more! Expect some downtime, but in no time everything will be up at nicksblog.net. Thanks!

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: Nick's Blog is the blog of Nick McClellan, a multimedia journalist and University of Missouri grad student. The blog has taken on many forms since beginning early in 2002. You can expect to get a dose of political news, journalism, film, music and anything that's interesting (to me at least). I will graduate from the University of Missouri-Columbia in 2010 with aspirations of becoming a political journalist and continuing my blogging for a respected online newspaper or Web site. The most recent incarnation of this blog was updated frequently in the run-up to the 2008 election. However, as the life and responsibilities of being a grad student have sunk in, I have had little to no time to dedicate to blogging. Please catch me on Twitter, though, where I find I have more time for frequent 140-character updates. You'll be happy to know that, in what spare time I have between researching my thesis and preparing to move to Washington D.C., I am working on a relaunch of this site as a blogging publication, amateur photography showcase and personal Web site. More about me? Alright. I matriculated at the University of Georgia before graduating in 2005. I moved to California soon afterward, getting a job as copy editor for the Visalia Times-Delta in Tulare County, Calif. After a year, I was elevated to the job of multimedia reporter — a first for the paper — and that job ended in August 2008. I produced hundreds of videos and worked to budget stories and train other reporters in multimedia. I began attending grad school at Missouri soon afterward. This past summer, I was a News21 reporting fellow at The University of Maryland, reporting on racial identity and the political landscape. In my spare time, I enjoy blogging, running, hiking, biking and working out. I have a lifetime goal of running a marathon in all 50 U.S. states (I have so far finished races in five states). That's all for now.

item.title: Past blog archive
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
This blog has had many forms in the past few years. It began as a personal blog, briefly morphed into a short retrospective on my move to California then returning as a generalized blog spouting my perspective on many different things. The latter blog, my "MovableType blog," has been integrated into the current theme. You can find the other previous sites below.

"Thursday"

My first Web site was named "Thursday." The point of this site was to develop my skills in Web design while chronicling my experience at the University of Georgia. Look for the blog/journal section to read my writings from this period.

Letters

Between my college Web site and my "MovableType" blog, I did produce this one-off blog about my move to California. It's purpose is to be a post script to the "Thursday" Web site and features some of the photos I shot of my trip.

item.title: Waiting for a star to call
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
After months of speculation, Democratic presidential nominee-in-waiting Barack Obama is set to name his running mate via text message to millions of supporters, possibly today.
Obama not ready to name running mate just yet The Associated Press By Liz Sidoti WASHINGTON — Presidential candidate Barack Obama said Friday the running mate he has chosen — but has not yet announced — had to meet three standards to join the Democratic ticket: Prepared to be president, able to help him govern and willing to challenge his thinking. Those criteria did little to narrow the guessing game as Obama prepared for a massive rally in Illinois on Saturday to present his No. 2 to the nation and undertake a pre-convention tour of battleground states. He planned to disclose his choice through text messages to supporters, perhaps as early as Friday. "Obviously, the most important question is: Is this person ready to be president?" Obama said in an interview aired Friday on "The Early Show" on CBS. Second, he said, was: "Can this person help me govern? Are they going to be an effective partner in creating the kind of economic opportunity here at home and guiding us through some dangerous waters internationally?" And, he added: "I want somebody who is going to be able to challenge my thinking and not simply be a 'yes person' when it comes to policymaking.
I half expected to receive my text message Wednesday, while I was surrounded by other journalism graduate students undergoing orientation at Mizzou. If you can imagine the ideological makeup of our incoming class (and I'm sure you can), you can imagine my cell phone would have joined a chorus of other ringtones and beeps. It's a shame I didn't get the message then, perhaps I should find the closest hacky sack ring to replicate the same effect. Just about anyone has an interest in Obama's decision as the Democratic nominating contests this year became one of the most drawn out primary processes in recent history, making the choice for VP very crucial. Does Obama give the nod to Clinton, the Democrat's silver medalist, or does he pick someone like Delaware Senator Joe Biden, Indiana Senator Evan Bayh or Kansas Governor Kathleen Sebelius? In a joking exchange with reporters yesterday, Obama responded to repeated questions as to when he will be announcing his running mate by saying, "Wouldn't you like to know?" Frankly, I think Obama is coming from in a position of arrogance given the nature of his handling of his VP nomination. Voters have a right to know who Obama has picked for the job and interested parties might find themselves a bit annoyed by the Obama camp and their juvenile press games. Yeah, I signed up for the text message, but after a few moments of thought, a gasp or perhaps a raised eyebrow, I'll delete the text message and direct the same interest and analysis to John McCain. My advice: Get it over with, Obama is putting too much emphasis on a Saturday headline. Extra credit: If you want to take advantage of your Obamasochistic friends with vicious headgames, play Wonkette's "Freak Out Your Friends With Fake Obama VP TXT" game. It's sure to have someone screaming. Does anyone have Hillary's cell phone number?
item.excerpt:encoded: Will you ready for that 3 a.m. text message?

item.title: Platform of platitudes
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
As the election nears, the term of the 110th Congress of the United States is nearing a close. Republicans, who were chased from office in 2006 for years of corruption, hypocrisy and pork barrel spending, have apparently learned the err of their ways, exclaiming that they are the party that will deliver Congress from frivolous spending and government waste. But, unfortunately, even those noble priorities have fallen by the wayside in the throws of an election year:
Battle against lawmakers' pet projects fades The Associated Press By Andrew Taylor WASHINGTON — Whatever happened to the Republican Party's war on pork? It never was the full-fledged assault envisioned by conservatives, but the GOP's battle against parochial home-state projects sought by members of Congress has faded into oblivion. Just months ago, most Republicans in the House swore off pork barrel projects — at least until new reforms could be put in place. The moratorium on such "earmarks" was to be a key plank in the House GOP's fall platform, issues Republican candidates will emphasize in their campaigns. Since then, it's been supplanted by high gasoline prices and the weak economy as dominant campaign issues.
What can you expect from a party who's message shifts with the prevailing wind? The best you can expect from the Republican party is a promise of lower taxes (with most tax cuts going to corporations and the filthy rich) and the ellusive promise of smaller government. Of course, if the Bush years have taught us anything, smaller government often equates to some of the largest expansions of a government entitlement programs in recent years. More on that later. Don't be fooled, Republicans will say anything they can to hold onto power. Voters should not forget the rampent spending and waste orchestrated under their watch, including the Safe, Accountable, Flexible, Efficient Transportation Equity Act of 2005, one of the largest pork barrel spending bills to come out of the Republican Congress under Bush's watch. Of course that bill didn't fall in line with White House budget limits, but that didn't keep Bush from signing it (with a big grin on his face too). More on the Republican's shifting platitudes as the months progress and other pandering opportunities emerge (and yeah, I think that's Obama back there in the photo. Democrats are just as slimy as the rest of them).
item.excerpt:encoded: Noble party platforms scatter like dust in the wind.

item.title: Bush to withdraw troops — no, really
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: So I see this headline when I browse the AP news app on my iPod touch: Bush OKs deal for Iraq troop withdrawal. I'm sure this will be heralded by the White House as a completely different proposal than other withdrawal timetables offered by Democrats and certain presidential nominees. My amazement centers not on this reversal, but on the public's patience with an administration so blind to its failures and its well-minded critics. No credibility whatsoever.
item.excerpt:encoded: No, this plan is different that the defeat-o-crats, honest!

item.title: Is it Evan Bayh?
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Well, Drudge seems to think so:
FLASH: Fri Aug 22 2008 17:52:03 ET /// KMBC's Micheal Mahoney reports a company in Kansas City, which specializes in political literature, has been printing Obama-Bayh material... MORE... Gill Studios, would not confirm information about the material. They would not deny it either. At least three sources close to the plant's operations reported the Obama-Bayh material was being produced. The company is in the Obama FEC reports for previous work...
I love that it comes out like this. You can't keep a text message this big under wraps. I will be truly impressed if it turns out to be wrong since I'll have the "Dewey defeats Truman" screen shot on Drudge, but the bastard does seem to be right from time to time. Alright, back to the pointless wait... Oh, and on a side note, how weird is it going to be to say Obama/Bayh. I feel like snot might fly out of my nose just thinking about it. People are going to have to pop a breath mint if they are going to get through the Democratic convention with a duo like that.
item.excerpt:encoded: Drudge is on the offensive ... again.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » Sunday Blog: The Biden choice
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] the extent of Bayh’s consideration made it as far as a cheap bumper sticker knock off paraded on the Drudge Report. I should have seen through that trick, it totally lacked the blue [...]

item.title: Baby, it's Biden!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Well, according to most mainstream media, Joe Biden may be the next vice president of the United States. You'll find this news just about anywhere (goes to show those who signed up for the text message definitely weren't the first to know!)
Oh, and Drudge definitely fell for someone's idea of a joke. Evan Bayh? Thank God that's pronounced "bye" and not "bahh," because that would have been really unfortunate.
OK, so I'm putting this story to rest, I had my first night out in Columbia tonight and I'm tired! Veep reactions later, adios!
item.excerpt:encoded: Biden takes stage left on Obama ticket.

item.title: Bat versus cat
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: OK, so I might have failed to mention that the second night I stayed in my apartment in Columbia, Mo., I was terrifyingly awoken in the middle of the night but what I thought was someone or something pointing a gun in my face. I screamed like a girl, dove out of bed and had to sleep in the living room with my mother because of the most jarring night terror I've had in my whole life. Yeah, I'm supposed to be 25. So I thought maybe I had a ghost, right? Anyways, this week and pretty much every day I've spent in my new apartment has been fine, I haven't been a pussy like I was the second night I was here, so yay me. Well, that was the case until just about 20 minutes ago when I was awoken by the sound of a frightful squeak and the hurried pace of my 1-year-old cat, Sue (yeah, he's a boy named Sue, see the related post), I didn't know what was going on. All I knew was Sue was making such a big fuss about it. I follow him out into the living room, assuming he's found some rat or mouse or something when A FREAKING BAT FLYS DOWN TO ATTACK ME. I didn't scream like a girl this time, but I found it really dicey in the living room so I retreated to my bedroom. Suddenly the humor of the situation seized me as I watched my cat pace doggedly around my apartment as this poor bat flew circles around my living room light fixture. The poor thing would land every so often on the upper trim of the apartment only to watch the cat climb menacingly up couches, book shelves and shopping carts (yeah, you'll notice I have one of those in the photo) to capture and eviscerate him. Well, after I came to my senses and resolved to save the poor bat from the deathmatch with my cat, I fashioned my laundry basket and its lid into a sort of bat catching device that only the Joker would appreciate. The poor beast could echo-locate well enough not to fly into the cavernous obstacle, so I had to wait to scoop him into the trap when my cat had scared him into a corner. After a few squeaked protests, I watched the poor thing crawl from my laundry basket trap from the safety of my apartment deck door window, averting the crisis and freeing up fruitful blog time. Question, has this happened to you? Any Missouri people, are bats like household menaces or something?? This just happened to be the first night I let my cat roam my apartment instead of keeping him in my room with me (with food and bathroom facilities for him, mind you). Perhaps I should leave him in the living room more often so he can drum up any other intruding creatures and ghosts so I'm not bothered? Crazy! OK, I'm glad I got that out of my system.
item.excerpt:encoded: "You know, I have one simple request. And that is to have bats with frickin' laser beams attached to their heads!"

item.title: Sunday Blog: The Biden choice
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It's Sunday, so that means it's time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it's a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what's on the skillet. The dust has settled, the texts are sent and the choice has been made: Joseph R. Biden, the senator from Delaware, may very well be the next vice president of the United States. His ascension, leaked hours ahead of time to the press by loose-lipped Obama insiders, was officially announced to supporters via text message at just past 3 a.m. in the morning — a call that not many Americans were ready for, much less expected at such an early hour. Obama and Biden appeared together Saturday in Springfield, Ill., to show off their newly minted ticket. There, Biden introduced himself to the Obamass:
And ladies and gentlemen, is there no ordinary times, and this is no ordinary election. Because the truth of the matter is, and you know it, that American dream under eight years of Bush and McCain, that American dream is slipping away. I don't have to tell you that. You feel it in your lives. You see it in your shrinking wages, and the cost of everything from groceries to health care to college to filling up your car at the gas station. It keeps going up and up and up, and the future keeps receding further and further and further away as you reach for your dreams. You know, ladies and gentlemen, it is not a mere political saying. I say with every fiber of my being I believe we cannot as a nation stand for four more years of this. We cannot afford to keep giving tax cuts after tax cuts to big corporations and the wealthiest Americans while the middle class America, middle class families are falling behind and their wages are actually shrinking. We can't afford four more years of a government that does nothing while they watch the housing market collapse.
For the most part, Biden did well to introduce himself to the Obama movement, highlighting the strengths he brings to the Obama ticket. He pointed out that only four other senators hold seniority in Congress over him. He also did well the bridge the experience gap between himself and Obama by going out of his way to compliment the freshman senator on his brief career in the U.S. Senate. And, above all, Biden did best by slipping into his veep attack dog role, taking on his colleague and friend John McCain:
I must tell you, frankly, I've been disappointed in my friend, John McCain, who gave in to the right wing of his party and yielded to the very swiftboat politics that he so — once so deplored. And folks, campaigns for presidents are a test of character and leadership. And in this campaign, one candidate, one candidate has passed that test.
This is one complaint I've always had about McCain. While he did not stand idly by as the Republican smear machine sullied the noble war record of former Democratic presidential nominee John Kerry, he has nonetheless allowed these same dishonorable elements to integrate into his own campaign's "Truth Squad," helmed by none other than the alumni of a certain political group, Swift Boat Veterans for Truth. Only time will tell if Biden will truly help carry the Obama ticket to victory. I find the choice of Biden really interesting since it was Biden's own presidential ambitions that were shot down when he said of Obama: "I mean, you got the first mainstream African-American who is articulate and bright and clean and a nice-looking guy. I mean, that’s a storybook, man." Hopefully Biden's big mouth will not get him or his running mate in such trouble again. For the most part, the press has had little to add to the hoopla. There was an interesting story in the New York Times about the process Obama took to name his running mate, with interesting details about other prospects, both vetted and unexplored:
In Obama’s Choice, a ‘Very Personal Decision’ By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg The New York Times ... The plans for the announcement began to take shape in early July. Until the end, aides said, a small team inside the Chicago headquarters planned for four possibilities: Mr. [Joseph] Biden, Mr. [Evan] Bayh, Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia and Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas. Speeches were written, media plans were made and private planes were at the ready to take any of the four to Springfield, Ill. ... In the waning days, several people close to Mr. Bayh said he remained upbeat over the possibility that he would be Mr. Obama’s choice. He had met with Mr. Obama several times, and the amount of information Mr. Obama’s staff had asked for was beyond anything Mr. Bayh — who has been in contention for the vice-presidential position at least twice before — had experienced. Mr. Biden, meanwhile, was viewed as undercutting himself with his own behavior as reporters staked out his Delaware residence. When Mr. Biden returned home in his white pickup truck from a garbage dump and made an off-color joke to camera crews last week, an e-mail message circulated among Mr. Bayh’s closest associates that read, “Keep talking Joe, please keep talking.” He did not.
Unfortunately, the extent of Bayh's consideration made it as far as a cheap bumper sticker knock off paraded on the Drudge Report. I should have seen through that trick, it totally lacked the blue gradient color scheme we have all come to love and loath from the Obama campaign. But the most interesting addition to the Democratic campaign had to be Frank Rich's advice that the motto "Change We Can Believe In" stay a fond memory of the primary process as the Democrats move into the endgame. Barack Obama is going to need more than to spread the fever if he's going to unite the county. He's going to have to build a campaign Americans can actually believe instead of being goaded into believing:
Last Call for Change We Can Believe In Frank Rich The New York Times As the real campaign at last begins in Denver this week, this much is certain: It’s time for Barack Obama to dispatch "Change We Can Believe In" to a dignified death. This isn’t because — OMG! — Obama's narrow three- to four-percentage-point lead of recent weeks dropped to a statistically indistinguishable one- to three-point margin during his week of vacation. It’s because zero hour is here. As the presidential race finally gains the country's full attention, the strategy that vanquished Hillary Clinton must be rebooted to take out John McCain. ... How we dig out of this quagmire is the American story that Obama must tell. It is not a story of endless conflicts abroad but a potentially inspiring tale of serious economic, educational, energy and health-care mobilization at home. We don’t have the time or resources to go off on more quixotic military missions or to indulge in culture wars. (In China, they’re too busy exploiting scientific advances for competitive advantage to reopen settled debates about Darwin.) Americans must band together for change before the new century leaves us completely behind. The Obama campaign actually has plans, however imperfect or provisional, to set us on that path; the McCain campaign offers only disposable Band-Aids typified by the "drill now" mantra that even McCain says will only have a “psychological” effect on gas prices. ... Obama should go after McCain’s supposedly biggest asset — experience — much as McCain went after Obama’s crowd-drawing celebrity. It is, after all, not mere happenstance that so many conservative pundits — Rich Lowry, Peggy Noonan, Ramesh Ponnuru — have, to McCain’s irritation, proposed that he “patriotically” declare in advance that he will selflessly serve only a single term. Whatever their lofty stated reasons for promoting this stunt, their underlying message is clear: They recognize in their heart of hearts that the shelf life of McCain’s experience has already reached its expiration date. Is a man who is just discovering the Internet qualified to lead a restoration of America’s economic and educational infrastructures? Is the leader of a virtually all-white political party America’s best salesman and moral avatar in the age of globalization? Does a bellicose Vietnam veteran who rushed to hitch his star to the self-immolating overreaches of Ahmad Chalabi, Pervez Musharraf and Mikheil Saakashvili have the judgment to keep America safe? R.I.P., "Change We Can Believe In." The fierce urgency of the 21st century demands Change Before It’s Too Late.
My two cents? Clinton was the unpopular, difficult, but right decision. She would have sent a shock to the base, granted, but it didn't have to be so rocky. Had Obama softened to the idea of a Clinton VP spot and actually vetted her as a candidate, her base would have recognized the pragmatism and courage Biden so eloquently spoke of. Lines drawn could have been blurred and a weary Democratic voting bloc could have embraced the dream team. Now, we'll never know. But Obama is going for much more than a powerhouse left-leaning moderate ticket. He has the best shot of bringing liberal government to the highest office in the country, and while he might compromise on Iraq, offshore drilling and other popular platitudes, he still hasn't taken his eyes off of the biggest potential prize.
item.excerpt:encoded: The right choice, or the right choice for the movement?

item.title: Dying for a MacBook Pro
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Technology

  • Delivery of new iPods and Macs seem imminent, as Apple ramps up for likely press events. The popular rumor at the moment circulates around a Sept. 9 press event for the fourth generation iPod nano and second generation iPod touch. MacBook and MacBook Pro updates are likely to come later in September.

Politics

  • Senator Edward Kennedy made a surprise appearance at the Democratic National Convention Monday, months after undergoing risky surgery to treat a brain tumor. To thunderous applause, Kennedy exclaimed, "Nothing — nothing — is going to keep me away from this special gathering tonight."
  • During his wife's speech, soon-to-be Democratic presidential nominee Barack Obama misidentified the state city he was speaking from. In a live video message, Obama said, "I'm here with the Girardo family here in St. Louis." He was corrected by his daughter Sasha asked her father to repeat what city he was in. Staged political save from a 9-year-old Democratic operative? Was the little rascal wired??

Journalism

  • The Honolulu Observer, a Gannett newspaper, cut another 27 employees as part of a company-wide round of layoffs that may send as many as 600 into unemployment. Liveblogging the cuts is Gannett Blog, an independent journal about Gannett Co. Inc. run by a former USA TODAY reporter who accepted a buyout earlier this year. In other news, McClatchy widened its layoffs by extending buyout applications at select papers, including the Sacramento Bee and the Fresno Bee. An estimated 10 percent of the company's work force was already cut earlier this year in the first of obviously a series of budget cuts.
item.excerpt:encoded: Morning edition: August 26, 2008

item.title: Confessions of a soon-to-be Windows expat
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: In 2004, I bought a Dell Inspiron 5150 notebook — at the time, a major improvement upon my craptastic Prostar notebook computer, which now takes up valuable shelf space in my closet. Well, 4 years later, 3 hard drives, two motherboards, two keyboards, one 3-year warranty and a court settlement, this computer has transformed into a steaming pile of 21st-century hardware. It weighs a ton, the hard drive is at full capacity, it took an hour to shut down last night and I fear worried stares and awkward glances if I ever bring it to class. No wonder I like my iPod touch so much, anything is better then my Dell from hell! Of course, it wasn't always like this. The smartests thing I ever did was get the 3-year warranty. And while the computer turned out to be horribly designed, resulting in a class-action lawsuit, I did get a warranty extension to cover fixes related to the suit. And despite all of my problems, the computer still plugs along, protecting my precious mp3s and even staying strong long enough for me to design another Web site (albeit very slowly). But something has weaned me from the teet of Microsoft after all these years. Maybe it was working all those years on my gorgeous G5 supertramp at the Times-Delta or maybe it was my glorious iPod touch that has made me see the light, but I think I'm ready to jump to Mac. And I'm not the only one. It's been a while since I've been on a college campus and this is the first week of classes (and yes, the photo above is from a Mizzou class — thankfully, not one of mine). And let me tell you, I've seen more MacBooks and MacBook Pros in the last 2 days to be truly stunned. Macs are obviously working for someone. I feel truly dated to come from the generation Dell claimed. It's a shame converting to "now" is going to be so expensive. A top-of-the-line 17-inch MacBook Pro runs about $2,600 for a student, and that's without likely RAM upgrades and Apple Protection Plans I'd likely opt in for. The whole thing is going to cost $3,000, which is a lot to pay considering I got my last computer for just under $1,500. But is a Mac worth it? They say Macs are the best for design. I intend to continue my adventures in Web design. But buying all those programs I bought for a PC again for Mac? Is it worth it? And is Windows really that bad? I'm still an XP user, and even if I wanted to go to Vista I don't have enough memory for it, but it can't be as bad as those "Mac and PC" commercials make it out to be. Anyways, I've more or less decided on getting the MacBook Pro, but rumors say that an update is coming soon and that prices may be coming down. Problem is, it may be late September before the new version is released. And you know that's not coming to my door in less than 2 weeks — maybe longer. So can my Dell last? Am I just days away from a meltdown? How many "disk cleanups" do I have to do until I need to start sacrificing precious mp3s? Hopefully that's unlimited, I would die if I lost my music. Here's hoping Apple spills the beans soon on what's certain to be a fabulous computer, one that in 4 years won't be a source of pain and embarrassment.
item.excerpt:encoded: To Mac or not to Mac, that is the question.

item.title: 'Showgirls' scribe emerges from devil's back room
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
If there's one thing I have passion for, it's journalism (I guess, I'm getting another degree in it after all). If there's another, it's "Showgirls." Writer Joe Eszterhas, who famously received $2 million for the script to the box office disaster "Showgirls," has emerged from a spirited bout with throat cancer and written a book on faith, a marked departure given his previous writing experiences with other such Hollywood gems as "Basic Instinct" and "Sliver."
'Basic Instinct' author writes book about faith Toledo, Ohio, Blade Joe Eszterhas' latest book is a shocker, but not the kind that made him rich and famous. The upcoming release from the man who penned dark thrillers such as Basic Instinct and Jagged Edge tells the story of his spiritual conversion and his newfound devotion to God and family. In Crossbearer: A Memoir of Faith, to be published Sept. 2 by St. Martin's Press, Mr. Eszterhas describes how his life got turned around during the summer of 2001. He and his second wife, Naomi, had just moved from Malibu to a suburb of Cleveland - where he had grown up; she was from nearby Mansfield. They felt Ohio would be a better, more wholesome place to raise their four boys (he had two grown children from his first marriage). A month after the move, Mr. Eszterhas was diagnosed with throat cancer. Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic removed 80 percent of his larynx, put a tracheotomy tube in his throat, and told him he must quit drinking and smoking immediately. ... "I was going crazy. I was jittery. I twitched. I trembled. I had no patience for anything. … Every single nerve ending was demanding a drink and a cigarette," he wrote. He plopped down on a curb and cried. Sobbed, even. And for the first time since he was a child, he prayed: "Please God, help me." Mr. Eszterhas was shocked by his own prayer. "I couldn't believe I'd said it. I didn't know why I'd said it. I'd never said it before," he wrote. But he felt an overwhelming peace. His heart stopped pounding. His hands stopped twitching. He saw a "shimmering, dazzling, nearly blinding brightness that made me cover my eyes with my hands." Like Saul on the road to Damascus, Mr. Eszterhas had been blinded by God. He stood up, wiped his eyes, and walked back home a new man. ... "I find it mind boggling that with nearly 70 percent of Americans describing themselves as Christians, and witnessing the success of The Passion of The Christ and The Chronicles of Narnia, that Hollywood still doesn't do the kinds of faith-based and family-value entertainment that people are desperate to see," Mr. Eszterhas said. He has turned down hefty offers to write scripts for movies with sinister plots and dark themes like the 16 other ones he wrote that made it to the screen- some paying as much as $3 million a script. Mr. Eszterhas said he spent too much of his life exploring the dark side of humanity and does not want to go there anymore. ... "Frankly my life changed from the moment God entered my heart. I'm not interested in the darkness anymore," he said.
Eszterhas was of course noted a few years ago for publicly rebuking his previous attempts of using smoking in film as a way to infuse sexiness into his films, all a result of the throat cancer that he has now triumphed over. But this strip joint junkie is giving up all naughty influences, nixing any chance of "Showgirls 2: Nomi does L.A." But what future projects might we expect from Eszterhas? If he's right, and 70 percent of moviegoers crave a fresh, Christian influence in film, why not give the people what they want? Certainly "Showgirls" can be infused with more obnoxious Christian imagery (if you know anything about the film, it's already chuck full). Perhaps Nomi Malone strolls into Toledo, Ohio, on a vicious streak of booze, crack and sex, and like Saul on the road to Damascus, is blinded by the glory of gospel sage Crystal Connors, who saves her from her wicked ways before stepping back to let Nomi blaze a new path in worshiping God. That's certainly worth stripping for.
item.excerpt:encoded: "As the naked bride of Jesus, Crystal Connors, performing in a jukebox..."

item.title: UPDATED: Now it's the Republicans' turn
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Or is it? Wait, is the Democrat convention over yet? I couldn't be too soon for McCain...
McCain to announce running mate on Friday By Elisabeth Bumiller and Michael Cooper International Herald Tribune WASHINGTON: Senator John McCain has decided on his running mate, two Republican strategists in contact with McCain's campaign said Wednesday. He is expected to reveal his choice at a rally at a basketball arena in Dayton, Ohio, at 11 a.m. Friday. McCain's decision is known only to his small inner circle of advisers, no more than three or four people, who have refused all public discussion on the matter. Republicans close to the campaign said that the top contenders remained the same three men who have been the source of speculation for weeks: former Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, Governor Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota and, possibly, Senator Joseph Lieberman, independent of Connecticut. It was unclear how seriously McCain was considering his good friend, Lieberman, who favors abortion rights and whose selection could set off a revolt among delegates at the Republican National Convention next week in Minneapolis-St. Paul as well as a furious backlash among Christian conservatives, a crucial voting bloc of the Republican Party. But as recently as Tuesday, McCain was said to still be entertaining the idea of Lieberman, who was Al Gore's running mate on the Democratic presidential ticket in 2000.
The buzz is that news of the running mate will leak at 6 p.m. tonight. Isn't that funny, that's just when Barack Obama is scheduled to address his followers at the newly fashioned Greek temple at Invesco Field in Denver. Could McCain be trying to steal Obama's torch, so to say? Personally, I highly doubt that Joe Lieberman will follow his 2000 Democratic VP run with a 2008 run on the Republican ticket. I think this late speculation is just a smokescreen before the real candidate, Mitt Romney or Tom Ridge, at worse, will emerge later today. I'll be sure to blog as best I can when I hear the news. UPDATE: According to sources, Minnesota Gov. Tim Pawlently has canceled remaining press appearances today. Does this mean Pawlently is the pick? I sure hope not, McCain/Pawlently sounds so Dole/Kemp to me...but somehow the Republicans soared with Bush/Cheney, so maybe it's not so bad. UPDATE: Word has also come out that Mitt Romney's family is getting a security upgrade sweep. Has Secret Service protection been forwarded to the new veep pick? Call me presumptuous, but if McCain picks Romney, he's reaching right, hoping to preserve the conservative movement and build a coalition ala Bush. But if Bush picks Ridge or Lieberman, he's going to piss off conservatives and hope for a more right-of-center electorate to sweep — or nudge — into office.
item.excerpt:encoded: Stop looking at the Democrats and look at me now!

item.title: UPDATED: Has history moved onto the Republican ticket?
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
UPDATE: The buzz is squarely on Palin. Evidence is really strong that she's in Dayton today to accept the VP spot. Very interesting...we shall see... Speculation over John McCain's pick for vice president continues to boil. I'm surprised word of the choice didn't leak in the early morning hours, it seems McCain has decided to reveal his decision at an hour most Americans are awake. Right now, popular speculation lands on Sarah Palin, the popular Republican governor of Alaska. She's pro-life. She's known for fighting government corruption, both Republican and Democrat alike. And best of all, she's got the Eskimo vote, a key constituent for McCain in the American ice box. The blog Change and Experience, a Web site organized by former Hillary Clinton supporters that now support McCain, reports that a private jet left Alaska last night bound for Middletown, Ohio, a mere 30-minute drive from the Dayton, Ohio, rally where McCain will introduce his VP pick to the world. Is this evidence that Palin is indeed the Republican pick for vice president? It would make things very interesting in light of the Democrat's history making ticket. But on another note: Does McCain really think he can woo Clinton supporters with a pro-life female VP candidate? I'm thinking a fringe 10 percent might be fooled, but that can't be a major threat to the Democrats. It would make things very interesting, though. Keep checking back, I'll post confirmation when I have it. UPDATE: As quickly as speculation flared, it has dissipated. Palin is watching fireworks in Alaska, apparently. I mean, I'd much rather go to the armpit of America, Dayton, and lock hands with John McCain in a bid to keep the White House, wouldn't you? Also, all indications seem to point to Romney being out and I've read some interesting things about the candidate being a "mainstream Republican" pick, meaning no pro-choicers. Who is it then?? UPDATE: Well, the Dayton Daily News has fired up the speculation again:
MIDDLETOWN — A Gulfstream IV jet owned by a firm in Kirkland, Wash., landed at Hook Field Municipal Airport late Thursday night is believed to have had Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin on board as a passenger. National media outlets have identified the first-term Alaska governor, the first woman elected to the position, as a possible vice presidential candidate for Arizona Sen. John McCain, the presumptive GOP presidential nominee. McCain is in Dayton today and is expected to announce his running mate sometime later today at the Nutter Center at Wright State University. According to Rich Bevis of B&B Aero, the fixed-based operator at Hook Field, the jet, a Gulfstream IV which has the flight range to fly from Alaska to Europe, landed at about 10:15 p.m. Thursday, Aug. 28. Bevis said the woman "was a real close match to Palin" and added that the flight crew that's based in the Seattle area was told to fly to Anchorage to pick up their party and fly to Middletown. Bevis said the jet had a woman, two teenagers and two men on board and that a couple of white vans met the plane, gathered their gear and took the party to an undisclosed location.
If it isn't her, who can it be? Lieberman and Ridge are certainly not "mainstream Republican." A dark horse? So exciting!
item.excerpt:encoded: Stealing the Democrat's thunder?

item.title: UPDATED: It's still Palin
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
UPDATE: Major MSM confirmation, Fox News has confirmed it. I mean, you know McCain's flak has them in his pocket, so that's word enough for me. Interesting choice, I would argue not "mainstream Republican." It's going to be an interesting convention next week! CNBC is calling it.
Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin Is McCain's VP Pick: Source By John Harwood CNBC Political Correspondent Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin, a self-styled "hockey mom" who has only been governor for a little over a year, is GOP Presidential candidate John McCain's choice for Vice President, CNBC has learned. According to a Republican strategist, Palin is the nominee, though McCain's campaign has not comfirmed this. The vice presidential pick, which has been a closely guarded secret, is expected to be announced later Friday.
Hopefully this isn't a red herring, I think it may be the real deal. Who else could it be if it's not Romney, Ridge or Lieberman? UPDATE: Christian News Wire, another hot source, is also confirming Palin Where are you Drudge? UPDATE: Could Palin be on hand for a purported GOP talent show? Says Mark Halperin at Time's The Page. UPDATE: Now the Chicago Tribune has jumped on board the Palin boat. Where's official McCain confirmation? And why does Palin's flak like to lie about her schedule in Alaska? Why must Republicans lie?! UPDATE: Bill Kristol says it's Palin. I said it's Palin, and I'm always right, why don't the blogs cite me? I'm just waiting for some MSM verification before I go mute. Definitely expect veep analysis on Sunday.
item.excerpt:encoded: Change we can believe in?

item.title: Wonkette gives us our first look at McCain/Palin
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: I think this is hilarious. The choice of Palin is in no way a Republican's desperate attempt to stay relevant and current in a game-changing election. Make sure to view the full hilarity of Wonkette on the new McCain/Palin pairing. I've been reading some interesting things about our new soon-to-be veep. Michelle Malkin has a jones for her hating on polar bears. Palin is also a bit sketchy on what exactly a vice president does. Like I said, give me half a weekend for it to sink in and I'll be happy to have a go at Palin. All I gotta say now is I can't wait for the veep debate in St. Louis this year — here's hoping I'm there!
item.excerpt:encoded: Daddy, you'll take care of me, won't you?

item.title: Sunday Blog: The McCain ticket
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It’s Sunday, so that means it’s time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it’s a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what’s on the skillet. On Friday, John McCain sent a shock to the electorate when he choose Sarah Palin, Alaska governor and conservative stalwart, as his running mate in the 2008 election. The choice of Palin is historic: she is the first female Republican running mate and has the potential of being the first woman to hold the second highest office in the country.
McCain Chooses Palin as Running Mate By Michael Cooper and Elisabeth Bumiller New York Times ... “She’s not from these parts, and she’s not from Washington, but when you get to know her, you’re going to be as impressed as I am,” Mr. McCain told a midday rally of 15,000 people in a basketball arena here shortly before Ms. Palin, with her husband and four of her children, strode out onto the stage.
Interesting way to introduce your running mate. Of course, it's almost certain McCain is still running on his first impressions of the governor because he only met her for the first time earlier this year. But never mind that, this nomination is historic and unprecedented for a Republican presidential ticket.
Within moments, Ms. Palin made an explicit appeal to the disappointed supporters of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton by praising not only Mrs. Clinton but also the only other woman in American history who has been on a presidential ticket, Geraldine A. Ferraro, Walter F. Mondale’s Democratic running mate in 1984. “Hillary left 18 million cracks in the highest, hardest glass ceiling in America, but it turns out the women of America aren’t finished yet, and we can shatter that glass ceiling once and for all,” Ms. Palin said to huge applause.
Very provocative appeal to women, Mrs. Palin. Democrats have in fact just put to rest a bruising primary campaign which featured race and gender as two very potent issues. Hillary Clinton, after all, came just a few million votes and a handful of delegates away from possibly taking the highest office in the country. But how does Palin's ascension equate to disaffected Hillary supporters who have been cold to the Obama movement? As nervous Republicans have watched a fed-up electorate mobilize enthusiastically around Democratic prospects for presidents, right wingers have been desperate to find an in to dismantle the liberal love fest. Bloggers like Michelle Malkin have labored excessively to expose cracks in their Democratic opposition's consensus by unleashing the PUMAs — that stands for "Party Unity My Ass" — and these cats essentially have dumped Obama for McCain. As cited on Michelle's blog:
“It makes us feel schizophrenic,” said Martha Burk, immediate past chair of the National Council of Women’s Organizations. “For the first time in history, we can see that a woman can and will be president,” she said. But the campaign, which Burk and many other feminists said was riddled with sexist attacks in the media, “exposed barriers that we thought we had overcome years ago,” she said. ... Hundreds of women have logged onto Clinton’s campaign website, with many insisting they will not vote for “that man” - Obama - and urging Clinton to run as an independent or challenge Obama’s nomination at the August convention in Denver. Many on the website pledged to vote for Senator John McCain of Arizona, the presumptive GOP nominee.
But is this strategy going to work? Will disaffected Clinton supporters flock to McCain? Does the historic nature of Palin's ascension steal any of the thunder from Obama's history-making campaign? What about McCain's appeals against Obama's readiness to be President? Sarah Palin has 2 years experience as governor along with her term as mayor of Wasilla, with a population of just over 5,000 people. How does this compare to Obama's years as a public servant in Chicago and the national experience he's had as senator?
6 things Palin pick says about McCain By Jim Vandehei and John F. Harris Politico The selection of a running mate is among the most consequential and the most defining decisions a presidential nominee can make. John McCain’s pick of Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin says a lot about his decision-making — and some of it is downright breathtaking. We knew McCain is a politician who relishes improvisation and likes to go with his gut. But it is remarkable that someone who has repeatedly emphasized experience in this campaign named an inexperienced governor he barely knew to be his No. 2.
Excellent Politico analysis, you should definitely read it. To close, I think I'll give my own analysis of the Sarah Palin choice. My first reaction is surprise: I remember thinking, on Friday morning, there is no way McCain is going to pick a political outsider. And if things were going better for McCain, he probably would have settled on someone like Tom Ridge of Joe Lieberman. However, this election is not in the Republican's corner and it's going to take leaps of faith akin to Sarah Palin in order to pull the White House from the Democrats' hands. The most surprising thing about the Palin choice so far has been conservative reaction. The sentiment, at least from the water carriers in the right-wing blogosphere, has been overwhelmingly positive. Michelle Malkin said she was impressed, RedState cited Palin's "smoking hot, naughty librarian" credientials and Blogs for Victory fawned of their veep's ability to shoot a machine gun. You might laugh at this sort of reaction, but McCain will definitely benefit from renewed conservative support. Dark Lord Dobson, evangelical mastermind and bigoted freakazoid, proudly admitted that he'd "pull that lever" now that Palin is on the ticket and the McCain campain reported nearly $4.5 million in donations on Palin's ascension day alone. She's potent, powerful, but she's not running for President. The Republicans are only fooling themselves if they think Palin adds any significant conservative cred to a McCain administration. They only wish McCain would step aside in 2012 so that Palin/Romney would take the reins. History says that people vote for president, not vice president, so Palin's immediate effects should be somewhat muted come election day. And I don't think disaffected Hillary supporters are going to vote for a wolf in sheep's clothing either. Palin is a pro-life, conservative firebrand and Hillary is a liberal icon — they don't mix. Also, Palin has just been co-opted in a desperate attempt to save the Republicans' chances at keeping the White House and Hillary has just ended an historic, 18-month campaign built on town hall meetings, coast-to-coast campaigning and interesting "conversations." You'll notice a lack of substance and connection in Palin's acceptance speech when you compare it to Hillary's convention speech. While Palin's ship seems to have been built to float in a safe harbor, Hillary's has rode the tempest of politics for over 18 years. I seriously doubt Palin's effect will be felt far outside female independents — however, still a coveted electoral prize for McCain. Despite all this, Palin's stock is rising and the Democrats have a potential race on their hands. Hillary's stock has risen too. Continued strong appeals to her base from her to buck back the Republican ticket could prove invaluable to the Obama campaign. She said she wanted to work for Obama, now it's time to get her hands dirty. Very interesting choice, that goes without saying. Is it the right choice? Absolutely. At least the right choice, right now. Now we'll see where the race goes from here.
item.excerpt:encoded: McCain pulls a hockey mom out of his hat.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
While my quote is correct, the context is not. I have never been a part of the movement to take votes to McCain. It will be disaster for women if the McCain/Palin ticket is elected, and I want no part of it. I am a former supporter of Hillary now solidly behind Obama.
Martha Burk

item.title: The downside of buying a Mac
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: The new MacBook Pro may come as early as Sept. 9, but is buying a Mac really the way to go? Here's one thought: Well, I'm upgrading an obnoxious, lawsuit-ridden Dell, so taking a gun to it is actually an exciting prospect. But, shhh! He might be listening.
item.excerpt:encoded: Hi, I'm a new Mac.

item.title: The iPods are coming!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Technology

  • Apple announced yesterday to its preferred media outlets that a special event dubbed "Let's Rock" will occur Tuesday in San Francisco. The event is likely to be the world's introduction to Apple's freshest iPods, including a redesigned iPod nano and a supped up iPod touch. Some other possible revelations at the event: iTunes subscription service, more iPhone features for iPod touch and the depressing lack of any MacBook Pro news. The lowdown on the new MacBook Pro is that it may come by October.
  • Designers everywhere will be interested to know that Adobe's Creative Suite 4 is nearly upon us. The new slate of updates for Photoshop, Dreamweaver, Flash and other design stables is likely to come within weeks of the scheduled webcast unveiling of the CS4 suite. Pricing and availability is likely to be revealed as well. The last time Adobe updated it's selection of design programmer heroin was back in March 2007, so I guess we're due for another fleecing.

Politics

  • President Bush and psuedo-Republican Senator Joe Lieberman praised John McCain at the second night of the Republican National Convention. Bush appeared via satellite from the White House, where he is coordinating relief efforts for Hurricane Gustav. His absence from the convention was the second time since Harry Truman a sitting president missed his party's convention, perhaps a tacit acknowledgment of his extreme unpopularity and even more so of his administration's gross neglect during Hurricane Katrina, just 3 years ago.
  • On former Democrat Joe Lieberman's participation, former New Jersey governor Thomas Kean said, "He's going to be punished by the Democratic Party and he knows it. But he wants to do it because he thinks he's the best candidate for president."
  • On the Sarah Palin controversy front, her daughter's baby daddy was revealed to the public when the New York Post discovered his MySpace page. Interestingly enough, the young man, Levi Johnston, was listed as "in a relationship," but curiously expressed, "I don't want kids."
item.excerpt:encoded: Morning edition: September 3, 2008

item.title: Bad blog news
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It appears my computer does not want to be patient and wait for my new MacBook Pro and has decided to adopt it's strange fits of not charging the battery. How wonderful! I'll be computerless for possibly months. Blogging will be light and possibly limited to my iPod (where I am now).
I'll try to keep up though!
Word of advice: Never buy a Dell if you expect it to work properly. If you are game for design muck-ups and multiple motherboard replacements, then by all means, buy a Dell!
item.excerpt:encoded: A computer built to last — 4 years

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Our Dell's work fine!

item.title: Sunday Blog: Republican agents of change?
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It’s Sunday, so that means it’s time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it’s a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what’s on the skillet. With the speeches said, the stages dark and, as Sarah Palin points out, the styrofoam Greek columns hauled back to the studio lot, the heart of the presidential campaign is upon us. But in the wake of the most watched political convention in history, I have to resonate on the subject of the Republican National Convention. It was a singular experience for me. Never has a choice been so clear, a party so defined than in this election. I know, things can be a lot worse, but I have no idea how a Republican can back out of the last 8 years and tell Americans with a straight face that they are in fact the agents of change that voters are thirsting for. But I saw that this week, and it was amazing. There is no doubt, Sarah Palin is a GOP superstar. She was absolutely the right choice for John McCain, who now has conservative Republicans loyal to his cause — or more accurately his ticket. On Day 3 of the convention she delivered a raucous speech, delivering some of the sharpest conservative barbs in this election. She's got everyone riled up and the red blogs are all standing in line now, but outside of the Republican's kumbaya-yas, what did the politicians actually say? I've watched both McCain and Palin's speeches, and while I readily admit their strong points, I am having a hard time finding the substance one would expect a party to deliver that can sufficiently explain to voters why American should re-elect Republicans to the White House:
We were elected to change Washington, and we let Washington change us. We lost the trust of the American people when some Republicans gave in to the temptations of corruption. We lost their trust when rather than reform government, both parties made it bigger. We lost their trust when instead of freeing ourselves from a dangerous dependence on foreign oil, both parties and Senator Obama passed another corporate welfare bill for oil companies. We lost their trust, when we valued our power over our principles.
The biggest incongruity of McCain's argument here is that both parties equally are to blame for the failures of the last 7 and a half years. Republicans have been in complete charge of the White House during that time and have dominated Congress for the majority of that time. And even as Democrats have wrested control of the legislature from Republicans, the minority still insists that issues they liken to national importance must pass a 60-vote threshold, a tactic Republicans once tried to destroy when Democrats used it as a last resort. But I will give McCain props where it's due: Obama did vote for the useless 2005 energy bill (you know the one, where Cheney secretly met with all those oil companies and gave them everything they wanted), while McCain voted against it. But there's still more curious protestations that Republicans roared. Obama's raising taxes, but I thought he said he would cut them? Not according to Sarah Palin, who said, "The Democratic nominee for president supports plans to raise income taxes, raise payroll taxes, raise investment income taxes, raise the death tax, raise business taxes and increase the tax burden on the American people by hundreds of billions of dollars." This is a tired line delivered by Republicans in every election. No matter what, every Democrat wants to raise taxes on the American people. But what has happened in the past 7 and a half years? Americans are paying more for food and gas. I don't know about you, but my payroll taxes are not surprisingly low. More Americans are getting hit with the alternative minimum tax, a fiscal mechanism that Democrats have tried to diffuse. What Obama has actually promised is to cut taxes for middle America and raise payroll taxes on the wealthiest Americans and corporations. When you really think about this and the crowd Ms. Palin is speaking to, I start to realize — Obama is raising taxes on them! Every rich Republican in the room has some dough at stake in this election! But Palin should know about stretching the truth to the benefit of others. Despite her fictional teleprompter errors, She still managed to get this doozy out: "And I have protected the taxpayers by vetoing wasteful spending: nearly half a billion dollars in vetoes. I suspended the state fuel tax, and championed reform to end the abuses of earmark spending by Congress. I told the Congress 'thanks, but no thanks,' for that Bridge to Nowhere." But we know that she did indeed oppose the Bridge to Nowhere, after she initially supported it. Can you say flip flop? And while she has earned the reputation as a reformer, to some degree, the insistence that she has strongly opposed earmarks is completely ridiculous. While mayor of Wasilla, the Washington Post points out, Palin employed a lobbying firm to secure almost $27 million in federal earmarks for the town of 6,700 residents. Despite these proven hypocrisies, Republicans still carry on, to the great esteem of rabid right-wing bloggers who seem to thrive on inaccuracy. In closing, I think McCain hit a good note when he encouraged Americans to get involved in their communities by putting their country first and getting involved:
If you find faults with our country, make it a better one. If you’re disappointed with the mistakes of government, join its ranks and work to correct them. Enlist in our Armed Forces. Become a teacher. Enter the ministry. Run for public office. Feed a hungry child. Teach an illiterate adult to read. Comfort the afflicted. Defend the rights of the oppressed. Our country will be the better, and you will be the happier. Because nothing brings greater happiness in life than to serve a cause greater than yourself.
But it's hard to believe what he's saying when his own running mate undermines his charge just one night earlier, saying, "I guess a small-town mayor is sort of like a "community organizer," except that you have actual responsibilities." Obama should be admired for his role as a community organizer in Chicago, not attacked. And the only reason Democrats — and rightly so, the media — have jumped on the Republicans for the inexperience of Sarah Palin is because McCain's argument about Obama's inexperience is a central plank of his whole campaign. The media's role is to expose hypocrisies, they should not be attacked for it. If Republicans followed their first standard instead of adopting double standards, maybe they would find Americans giving their "straight talk" the benefit of the doubt.
item.excerpt:encoded: Change you can't believe in

item.title: One stinkin' month
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: Bad news on the computer front. According to the rumor mill, my much anticipated MacBook update is coming October 14 -- one month and three days from today. Can you say, "BALLS?!" I'm dying over here! My laptop is paralyzed at the moment, propped up next to a book that angles the power cord in a way that makes it so 90 percent of the time the computer holds a charge. I have to wait a month plus to get a new computer, how will I survive? My first-gen iPod touch (which I'm still very happy with despite Apple's attempts to date it) can only do so much. I have thumbs with a depressing typing aptitude. So I'll try to keep up the blogging inbetween classes, dysfunctional computers and reporting. I mean, as long as Obama's hurling untimely turns of phrase and McCain is trying to convince conservatives that he's really Sarah Palin, I'm sure I'll find plenty of things to blog about.
item.excerpt:encoded: Your MacBook Pro ships in 34 days — and counting.

item.title: Cristal Connors for vice president
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
OK, so in the wake of my month long computer-related doldrums, not much is going to motivate me to opine at length here about much of anything, but every once and a while, something jolts the need to blog. And here's one of them.
See more Gina Gershon videos at Funny or Die
Yeah, I know, she's spoofing Sarah Palin, but let's give the thought of throwing our support behind a real candidate for the most useless job that's just a heartbeat away from the presidency: Cristal Connors. She has the experience to lead this country. Fresh from eight years as star of the little-known Vegas production Goddess, Connors has the stamina, tenacity and sequins to execute the office of the vice presidency. She knows how to cut through the red tape in Washington. As referenced in the "dark angel" number she once performed, while she might get pinned down now and again (and again), she will not hesitate to take out the whip and use it on snippy underlings. And she knows how the world works. As she once famously said, "There's always someone younger and hungrier coming down the stairs after you." So while conservatives might be hedging their bets on a McCain flunkie who'll spend more of her days shooting moose in the face than exploring the executive, you know Connors is going to be right behind McCain on those White House stairs, surfing his coat tails into power. I just hope she wears her skimpy metal-looking dress to all the cabinet meetings.
item.excerpt:encoded: It's amazing what paint and a surgeon can do.

item.title: Dell in hell, BYOB
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: Here commemorates my departed Dell, which went critical just hours after I was able to save my data and mp3s from its innards. It was a horrible computer and Oct. 14 couldn't come fast enough. So I'm gonna kick up the iPod blogging, it's going to be an interesting month. Sunday blogs will be spare, unless I'm itching to write something. Morning editions will also be nonexistant. But fear not! While my asshole Dell left me in a lurch, my iPod would never let me down. Here's looking toward an exciting, character-building month! Now does anyone have a MacBook they don't need for 32 days?
item.excerpt:encoded: ...and it takes the blog with it!

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » Sunday blog: The Apple tax
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] But how does this compare to PCs? Well, take my Dell for example. As I learned from the stellar disappointment that was my no name ProStar notebook I got in 2001, I got a 3 year warranty with my Dell computer. Like clockwork, the hard drive crashed after the first year (coincidentally just beyond the warranty that comes with the computer). The hard drive proceeded to crash two more times in the time that I had it (heck, it could be crashing again right now). In addition to this trouble, my Inspiron 5150 was subject to a class-action lawsuit over design flaws that led to motherboard issues. This has plagued me three times — the first time, I was ignorant of the issue and simply ordered a repair based on my warranty. The second time, after my warranty expired, I found out about the lawsuit and benefited from an extended warranty. The third time, well, just happened in the past month! [...]

item.title: T-minus 26 days: The MacBook mirage
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
This is the latest MacBook Pro photo making the rounds on the Apple rumor blogs. Yeah, I know, seems a bit soon for any promotional images, especially since all signs point to a Mac-specific Apple event on Oct. 14 (that's 26 days for you kids counting at home). But can this German reseller actually be onto something, or is this some Photoshopped play for attention. 9to5Mac.com has a nice roundup of rumors, linked from the Apple, Ink. module. Here's some things we can infer from the photo, assuming it's legit:
  • Keybored looks to have stayed the same: One likely change from the dated Powerbook design that currently graces the MacBook Pro is a keyboard reminiscent of recent Mac updates, like that of the MacBook Air or the Apple Bluetooth keyboard. It's hard to tell, but the keyboard in this photo is either unchanged or very similar to the status quo. My verdict? Good indication it's a fake.
  • iMac-like monior crust: But what happened to the iSight camera? Silly, iMac has it too, hidden in that lovely black mane. Just because you can't see it doesn't mean it's not there. And it reflects Apple design that is not circa 2003. My verdict? Possible nod that this photo is legit.
  • Hokey image: What program is that anyways? It matches another promotional image of the MacBook Pro. But does that mean it's legit? Who knows, but it plays really well in the "This is Photoshopped" category. My verdict? Strong indication it's fake.
So the final answer: Fakey fake fake. But there is still the glimmer of hope that this is the prelude to a sooner-than-expected updated MacBook Pro. We'll know soon enough. But for someone who's lucky to get an hour of work out of my Dell's corpse, the new MacBook Pros can't come quickly enough.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » T-minus 6 days: The brick is back!
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] what have we here, a new photo! And as opposed to the last two, this one is widely accepted as being legit. It appears to support 9to5Mac’s rumor of [...]

item.title: T-minus 18 days: The trackpad dock
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Well, here it is! According to 9to5mac, this is the latest "leaked photo of Apple's new MacBook Pro model, due to be released on Oct. 14. So, what makes it legit? What makes it a completely Photoshopped fake?
  • Glass trackpad: The popular rumor is that the new MacBook Pro models will have a glass trackpad, reminiscent of the iPhone and iPod touch models. In addition to the Apple Multi-touch possibilities, what else could this feature bring consumers? For one, the option of a dual display, ala Gameboy DS. And what does this fakey fake fake reveal? Why, a miniature dock in the glass trackpad! An interesting point, so Apple too. Verdict? Too legit...
  • Black-bordered screen design: Like the last fake knockoff, this MacBook Pro is again sporting the iMac like design of the black-bordered screen. And where are those vampire bite-like latch holes that the MacBook Pro is known for? At least this fake has a visible iSight camera like the last one. Verdict? So legit, it's scary...
  • The keyboard! Yes, the MacBook Air-like keyboard is actually on this fake miserable excuse of a leaked photo! Not only that, those MacBook Air-like curves also accompany the design. Say what you will about the over-the-top nature of how the alleged Apple Store employee is reflected in the screen, this mock up is quite impressive. Are we bound to see more of the same in the coming weeks? Verdict? Likely real.
But it's still fake! Well, fake until it turns out to be true when they actually release the little darlings on Oct. 14. Some say that waiting for the new Rev 1 MacBooks is silly. It's been said, "Why change something that's not broken?" Sure, the current generation is quite nice, but if my experience with iPods is any indications, any Apple buyer finds themselves brutally betrayed 6-8 months after their purchase only to see Apple release something WAY cooler. I'm just trying to make the most of my 6-8 month wait. Why buy one now only to regret it 2 weeks later? You can tell I'm so sick of my ailing Dell. Is it Oct. 14 yet?
item.excerpt:encoded: Glass trackpad *drool*

item.title: The economy is about the crater!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
I know I've been light on the blogging since my computer has gone south and I've begun to understand why grad students have such spare social lives, but this is a clip I can't help but watch five times:
