item.excerpt:encoded: Racing back to Washington, stopping for some Maybelline.

item.title: Massive Wall Street bailout fails
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
If at first you don't succeed, twist some arms and MAKE IT HAPPEN:
House Locked in Vote on Bailout Plan By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn New York Times WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives was locked in a historic vote on Monday on a $700 billion rescue of the financial industry, in what would turn out to be the biggest federal intervention into private markets in the nation’s history. With enough “no” votes recorded to defeat the measure, barring a change in position by some lawmakers, the markets were plunging early in the afternoon. Meanwhile, House leaders were trying frantically to turn some “no” votes into “yes” votes by pointing to the damage being done on Wall Street. Supporters of the bill had argued that it was necessary to avoid a collapse of the economic system, a calamity that would drag down not just Wall Street investment houses but possibly the savings and portfolios of millions of Americans. Opponents said the bill was cobbled together in too much haste and might amount to throwing good money from taxpayers after bad investments from Wall Street gamblers. Should the measure somehow clear the House, the Senate is expected to vote on Wednesday. The Jewish holidays and potential procedural obstacles made a vote before then virtually impossible, but Senate vote-counters predicted that there was enough support in the chamber for the measure to pass. President Bush has urged passage and spent much of the morning telephoning wavering Republicans to plead for their support.
I know I have been curiously silent on a lot of the economy developments (I continue to blame my miserable excuse of a computer. By the way, that's t-minus 15 days before a suitable replacement is ordered). Frankly, I think this bill should probably pass. I think Congress tried as best it could to produce an accountable bailout proposal with equal parts oversight and accountability to sufficiently dispel the scent of a steaming corpse our economy has sadly become. By the way, on word of the bill's failure, stocks are plummeting. So much for my 401(k)!
item.excerpt:encoded: The bill goes down.

item.title: Bailout bust raises the Barr
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It's hard to say which campaign is reeling most given the failure of the $700 billion bailout in the House today. Of course, no matter what you read, both campaigns are blaming the other guy. But what exactly is the other guy saying? No, not McCain or Obama. Bob Barr, the Libertarian Party candidate for president.
Congress Should Vote ‘No’ on Bailout, Says Bob Barr "The leaders of both the Republican and Democratic Parties are rushing ahead with their $700 billion bill," says Bob Barr, the Libertarian Party candidate for president. "Without a single hearing and without considering other solutions, Congress is preparing to put the typical American family on the hook for more than $8,000. Legislators in both parties need to stand up for the American people and say no," says Barr. "If bailouts are the answer, why hasn’t the $300 billion housing bailout worked? What of the $100 or more billion bailout of Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae?" Barr asks. "This bailout package doesn’t resolve the underlying problems. It merely transfers the liabilities to the taxpayers," he observes. "Instead, we need to make Wall Street take the hit for its irresponsible investment decisions." "The process will be painful. Some companies will go bankrupt. Some firms will go into receivership. Healthy companies will take over failing institutions," Barr adds.
I don't know about you, but from a consistant fiscally conservative perspective, Barr has a lot to offer. As opposed to Republicans who have no idea where they should land on the issue (65 Republicans voted for it and 133 voted against it), Barr seems to offer those who can't stand the stink of the bailout a safe ideological knoll to stand on. Interesting note related to me and Bob Barr: The man came to speak to my global affairs class in while I was attending high school in Georgia. At the time, he was fresh off his successful impeachment of President Clinton and failed attempt to remove him from office. I asked him a question on hate crimes. Woopie! I can't say I can agree that Barr's no-chance-in-hell presidential bid has any appeal for me, I don't understand why some Republicans at least can't admit that their party lacks complete credibility on the economy issue (well, at least some of them). Barr at least offers a consistent alternative. But why won't Republicans budge? I can't tell you. Of course, Democrats aren't swayed by the foreclosure moratoriums and NAFTA bashing from Green Party candidate Cynthia McKinney, so maybe the issue goes both ways.
item.excerpt:encoded: Bob Barr: What McCain doesn't want you to know.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » Politico copied my headline! (And sort of my idea)
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Here’s a link to my entry last month: Bailout bust raises the Barr. [...]

By now everyone has heard about the Tina Fey impressions of Sarah Palin. I mean, it was a match made in comedic heaven. Surely you've seen this week's offering:
But what about the actual interview? Especially some of Palin's scatterbrained answers:
Wow. I mean, her answer on Russia's proximity to Alaska was bad enough. Wow, maybe this bird will fly.

item.title: Reverse Palin derangement syndrome
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
A phase coined by conservative blogger Michelle Malkin, Palin derangement syndrome is when unhinged liberals create crazed stories about Republican vice-presidential nominee Sarah Palin. But what happens when unhinged conservatives attack their own for pointing out the obvious? That's what happened when Townhall.com columnist Kathleen Parker suggested that, given her shameful explanation of her supposed foreign policy credentials in an interview last week with CBS News' Katie Couric, Palin would be doing McCain a favor if she just stepped aside as his running mate. Come on, this is not an unhinged, crazed liberal opinion. There are credible reasons why Americans should doubt Palin's ability to serve a heart beat away from the commander-and-chief. So, the conservative reaction?
Speak correctly, or build a big bunker Kathleen Parker For the Chicago Tribune WASHINGTON — Allow me to introduce myself. I am a traitor and an idiot. Also, my mother should have aborted me and left me in a Dumpster, but since she didn't, I should "off" myself. Those are just a few nuggets randomly selected from thousands of e-mails written in response to my column suggesting that Sarah Palin is out of her league and should step down. Who says public discourse hasn't deteriorated? The fierce reaction to my column has been both bracing and enlightening. After 20 years of column writing, I'm familiar with angry mail. But the past few days have produced responses of a different order. Not just angry, but vicious and threatening.
While death threats might be considered elevating the level of discourse in fundamentalist, Islamic nations, is this really the debate we want to have in this country? Have the terrorists already won? Can't the right have the decency to accommodate at least a dissenting voice?
item.excerpt:encoded: When the right is wrong.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » Sunday blog: Could Palin flip the ticket?
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] interviews have tarnished the Alaska maverick’s image, even bringing some conservatives to openly opine that she step down from the ticket. But Palin’s performance Thursday largely dismissed those [...]

item.title: T-minus 10 days: The brick
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
After subjecting the Apple rumor fanbase to weeks of torture, 9to5Mac has finally let the cat out of the bag. The "brick" riddle, which first cropped up about a month ago, has had many wondering if Computerworld's Seth Weintraub was simply pawning off stinky bricks of his own, given his propensity for asinine riddles and crazy photo clues (Hey, I have a laser like that!). But, far be it from Weintraub to be a complete obnoxious dick, you have to give him credit for living up to his word:
The 'Brick' is... 9to5Mac.com The MacBook Brick is a block of high-quality, aircraft grade aluminum. It is the beginning. The beginning of what? It is the beginning of the new Apple manufacturing process to make MacBooks. It is totally revolutionary, a game changer. One of the biggest Apple innovations in a decade. The MacBook manufacturing process up to this point has been outsourced to Chinese or Taiwanese manufacturers like Foxconn. Now Apple is in charge. The company has spent the last few years building an entirely new manufacturing process that uses lasers (w/o sharks) and jets of water to carve the MacBooks out of a brick of aluminum.
Weintraub says the new manufacturing process for MacBooks constitutes the mother of all Mac rumors, and he says he would know. Of course, 9to5Mac, the "new kid on the block" of Apple rumor sites, has been responsible for credible rumors related to the aluminum iMac, the "fat" iPod nano, the fabulous iPod touch and the MacBook Air. Apparently, the new process will have many benefits. For one, because the aluminum casings of MacBooks will not need to be bent in production, the shell of the computer will be without inherent weak spots and will be incredibly strong. Also, the number of screws necessary to keep the computer together will be greatly reduced. The flip side of that means consumers may have to surrender even more routine MacBook maintenance to Apple Inc., but hopefully the thing at least comes with a removable/replaceable battery. We should know in a matter of days if the Oct. 14 release date is legit. I've noticed that the past few years, Apple sends out press invites at least a week before the actual event. That means we should get word sometime Monday or Tuesday from tech press heavyweights Engadget, Gizmodo and Ars Technica whether they have recieved invitations. Obviously, I'm very anxious to get my hands on one of the new MacBook Pros. We had a conference call this week from a graphics journalist with the New York Times! I mean, that's like my dream job, working interactive graphics with the New York Times. In order to get cracking on developing the skills I'll need for something like that, I'm going to need a computer that can move more than 5 feet from the kitchen, hence my MacBook anxiety. Let's hope it's a quick 10 days.
item.excerpt:encoded: Finally, a brick that doesn't stink.

item.title: Sunday blog: Could Palin flip the ticket?
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It’s Sunday, so that means it’s time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it’s a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what’s on the skillet. The beltway buzz following Thursday night's much watched vice presidential debate is that Republican Governor Sarah Palin scored a win over low expectations and potential pitfalls. It's true that a series of embarrassing press interviews have tarnished the Alaska maverick's image, even bringing some conservatives to openly opine that she step down from the ticket. But Palin's performance Thursday largely dismissed those critics. Rest assured, Palin is here to stay. But for how long, seriously? I mean, if she's elected with John McCain, she's on Number One Observatory Circle until at least 2012, but what if she loses? Is she going back to Alaska with a cadre of conservative strategists to plot the ouster of Obama in 2012? Is Palin the magic bullet that will wash away eight years of conservative blunders and restore Republicans to undisputed power? If so, Democrats had better duck, because conservatives may be ready to lock and load sooner than anyone realizes:
Pitbull Palin Mauls McCain By Frank Rich New York Times ... Palin is an antidote to the whiny Republican image ... Alaska’s self-styled embodiment of Joe Sixpack is not a sulker, but a pistol-packing fighter. That’s why she draws the crowds and "energy" that otherwise elude the angry McCain. But she is still the candidate for vice president, not president. Americans do not vote for vice president. So how can a desperate G.O.P. save itself? As McCain continues to fade into incoherence and irrelevance, the last hope is that he’ll come up with some new game-changing stunt to match his initial pick of Palin or his ill-fated campaign "suspension." Until Thursday night, more than a few Republicans were fantasizing that his final Hail Mary pass would be to ditch Palin so she can “spend more time” with her ever-growing family. But the debate reminded Republicans once again that it’s Palin, not McCain, who is their last hope for victory. You have to wonder how long it will be before they plead with him to think of his health, get out of the way and pull the ultimate stunt of flipping the ticket. Palin, we can be certain, wouldn’t even blink.
Wait, what?! Flipping the ticket? Is that possible? As was pointed out to me earlier this week, there is no constitutional barrier to dropping a vice presidential nominee from a ticket post convention but pre-Election Day. The downside of employing that option, of course, is that ballots are being printed up already. If McCain has another maverick up his sleeve, most voters would still be seeing McCain/Palin in their voting booths and not the name of her supposed successor. But what if the tables were literally turned? Given persistent questions about the possible recurrence of McCain's melanoma, is Rich right? Could McCain acquiesce to the vice presidential role and serve as Yoda to Sarah Palin? Such a move would certainly be a game changer. It would also constitute a cheap and desperate attempt by Republicans to do anything to hold onto the White House. I mean, seriously, you would think George W. Bush had been hiding a stash of gold at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave. since Jan. 20, 2001, given the Republican's desperate attempts to keep the ball in their court (or perhaps more accurately, the court under their feet). I don't know if such a move would be very wise. It would turn some heads, certainly (maybe a few heads would turn all the way around), but it would be patently unfair for Republicans to do this to Americans. One of the reasons we've been spinning around this election for so long is the give voters the opportunity to get to know the next president of the United States. As Palin herself pointed out during the debate, she's only been at this for five weeks and Americans are still getting to know her and understand the impact she would make as vice president. To suddenly thrust her into the top spot would be the ultimate insult to the Democratic process. If Palin has the mettle necessary to restore American credibility, fight her enemies and bring about economic recovery, why didn't she throw her hat in the ring years ago? The American presidency is anything but a beauty pageant, and I have every confidence that (at least most) Americans are smart enough to know the difference. So what does McCain really have up his sleeve? Just because flipping the ticket (jumping the shark?) isn't on the menu, that doesn't discount Republicans from making a bold gesture before Nov. 4. So what is it? After all, it's October, so it's time for a surprise. If anyone thinks Republicans are going to be rolled over by an Obama landslide, you are sorely mistaken. They won't take these waning days lying down. So if you've been watching from the sidelines, now is the time to join the game. Things are about to get interesting. ... oh, and you'll notice this is my first Sunday blog in a while. While I am still under the stress of computer paralysis, I can still turn the bastard on now and then. I'm feeling the need, despite ducking laborious reporting assignments and rabid despot MONKEYS, to blog more and more.
item.excerpt:encoded: President Sarah Palin, the October surprise?

item.title: Making Fiends is back! Long live Making Fiends!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: Does anyone remember Making Fiends? Did anyone ever watch Making Fiends? Making Fiends was a glorious Web cartoon that ran from 2003 to 2006 about the vicious Vendetta, her cavalcade of fiends and the innocent Charlotte, who just wants to be Vendetta's friend. Well, that cartoon ended unceremoniously with the cast of characters drifting out onto an uncertain sea. Well, two years later, we finally see where they ended up! Making Fiends creator Amy Winfrey, responsible for equally enjoyable creations Muffin Films and Big Bunny, sold her fiends to Nickelodeon, which has invested in Winfrey's idea and transformed her cartoon into a brand new Nicktoon. I guess this means Vendetta could be the next SpongeBob, but who knows. Winfrey says you can get schedule information here. She also alludes unconvincingly to the possibility that the new cartoons will begin becoming available online on Oct. 10. Here's hoping that's true (and also that they become available on iTunes, because I'd totally be game for a season pass!) Here's the new intro. For you fiendish virgins, check it out, it's very cool.
item.excerpt:encoded: It's back!

item.title: T-minus 7 days?: The deafening silence
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: For those of you playing at home, we should have received word of a spectacular Mac-centric Apple event in Cupertino sometime around 1 p.m. EST today. So what happened? NOTHING! Not good news if you are still clinging to your dead weight Dell, lousy excuse for a computer. So when are the Macs coming? Honestly, I don't know. I just don't know! Some dick on Mac Soda, the ill-fated wannabe rumor site that predicted media invites would be sent today, says that he knew invites would not be sent, but that the event would happen "in the coming weeks." Another supposed insider said, "The new laptops will be announced one week after the 14th (the 21st), but they will not be released until the friday after (oct. 24th)." Is he right? If he is, I think I might need to stop holding my breath, because I'm getting dizzy and kind of blue. NOVEMBER?! Are we going to elect a president before I get to have a furry, new MacBook?! Sure, what, Oct. 24th is only 17 days away, I can wait it out, right? Um, yeah, I guess, but it sucks BALLS. I totally wanted to play the savings account transfer game next Tuesday and give Apple lots of money. I guess I get 10 more days of interest. YIPPIE! OK, am I the only one hoping invites go out tomorrow for the 15th? Maybe Apple releases them the 14th and says, "Screw you press, you're not invited!" I know, I know, I'll stop. Isn't there a debate tonight anyways?
item.excerpt:encoded: "Excuse me sir, can I have my MacBook Pro just a wee bit sooner?"

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You don't get it. The Mac Soda guy didn't try to trick people... he made a mistake based on faulty info that an anonymous source gave him. Cut him some slack...

Maybe I'm being a bit harsh if you think I'm criticizing Mac Soda for blogging about the press invite. I actually don't so much blame Mac Soda for the faux story as I am criticizing those anonymous commenters who somehow know the press invites will be sent out next week. At least Mac Soda has the courage goes on the record.

item.title: T-minus 6 days: The brick is back!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded: Are MacBooks coming next week? Who knows?! The window is practically closed for a press invite, which is not a good thing. It's totally possible Apple will release the computers sans sloppy kisses from the press, and this coming Tuesday couldn't be a better choice — at least in the short term. As Apple Insider points out, Apple only has a handful of pre-Christmas rush weeks to get their products out for the populace. And Mac Soda points out that the week following, Oct. 21, has already been scheduled for Apple's third quarter conference call. Can't be distracting investors with brand spanking new MacBooks, can we? But what have we here, a new photo! And as opposed to the last two, this one is widely accepted as being legit. It appears to support 9to5Mac's rumor of Apples new hollowed brick manufacturing process. The photo appears to be a single bottom MacBook Pro piece. It should also be noted that the piece itself is thinner than the current generation of MacBook Pros. Ohh! Ahh! So what do I think? Well, I have a biased point of view, so keep that in mind. I feel as if I'm in exile from the computer age since I am waiting for the new MacBook Pros. My mp3s themselves are taking refuge on a Time Capsule. My iPod hasn't been synced in a month, waiting for some Mac lovin'. And I'm having to spend hours on campus working on convergence stories because my Dell can't handle the Adobe suite. So, again, when do I think these computers are coming out? I'm waking up bushy-tailed Tuesday morning, expecting the Apple Store to go down and come back up with armfulls of MacBooks. Screw the press. If I'm wrong, we are looking at late October (the 28th?!) or even November. Past that, we're talking about Macworld, and that's just scary. Maybe I should just freeze myself like Eric Cartman...
item.excerpt:encoded: Ohh! Laser-carved, water-sculpted Mac goodness. Ahh!

item.title: T-minus 1 day: New notebooks are upon us
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
At some point last week, in a haze of my Mac euphoria, I had to shut up. Given that the long-awaited media invites, the ones everyone had given up on, did indeed come out on Thursday, I decided to put the kibbosh on further MacBook Pro posts. I mean, you hit one note for too long and it gets kind of boring! If you are interested in the new Mac notebooks, hopefully I turned you onto some great Mac rumor Web sites, like Mac Rumors, 9to5Mac and even Mac Soda, the only site with the tenacity to boldly predict media invites (no matter how unlikely). Well, we are but hours away from the new MacBooks and MacBook Pros. Over the weekend, several photos were leaked from China depicting portions of the MacBook and MacBook Pro shells, giving us some more contextual details related to the release. Typically, on the night before a long-awaited Apple event, the rumor sites will conduct a rumor roundup to give readers an idea of what to expect based on what everybody thinks they already know. I'm going to do my own version of this, citing the sources accordingly:
  • Both the MacBook and MacBook Pro will benefit from the new "brick" manufacturing process detailed by 9to5Mac. This is a sticking point among the rumorati. Mac Rumors has cited industry expert and analyst opinions that largely dispute the feasibility of such a process. Besides, if the above case image is any indication, which may or may not be the product of a single brick of aluminum, it certainly requires other pieces to complete the shell. So why do I think this rumor is legit? Well, I noticed early on in the rumor buildup that Seth Weintraub referred curiously to the fact that the new MacBooks would be constructed from one piece of aluminum. I mean, they were already built from aluminum, why would it matter if it was one piece of aluminum? And this was before all the brick bullshit, so this is a point that has persisted in the months leading up to the event. In the original 9to5Mac brick reveal, Weintraub is careful to point out that, "That is where our information ends and speculation begins." I think a lot of the rumor sites are rightly taking issue with some of the speculation. The process, essentially, may be new, but it might not be as revolutionary as Weintraub understands it. I would say this rumor is the biggest leap any Mac enthusiast would need to take with this event. Why not make a bet. This is going to happen

  • NVIDIA chipsets: Apparently this is a big deal for technophiles. Apple Insider has confirmed this rumor. I guess it means the new Macs will have kick ass graphics and staying power. That's pretty cool, I guess. My Dell has trouble with some YouTube videos, so it would be nice to put this issue to rest.

  • Glass trackpad: This is also a Weintraub rumor that has had a lukewarm reception among the rumor sites. Given his track record, I am inclined to agree with him. Unfortunately, the photo above of the MacBook shell gives no indication of whether the empty spot would house such a device (what does the traditional trackpad spot look like on the older MacBooks?) Mac Soda speculated today that the glass trackpad could take advantage of some pending Apple gesture patents. I think the glass trackpad is a go, but it may not have the secondary screen many people think it might. None of this speculation clinches it, but again, you want to roll the dice on some the most interesting rumors.

  • Larger screens: This is something that's been going around the rumor blogs, but Apple might take this opportunity to convert all of their Mac notebooks to a true 16:9 format. Basically, that means that the MacBook Pros would be offered in 16-inch and 18-inch shells as opposed to the current 15-inch and 17-inch models. I guess this is possible, but it's hard to really predict. What's interesting about all these notebook shell leaks is that we're only seeing one part of the shell. What about the monitor? Just for fun, let's pretend this is going to happen. I can always cross it out tomorrow.

  • Cheaper prices: Apple Insider had an interesting post today with a headline, "$900 MacBook would grow Apple's addressable market by 67 percent." That got some shareholders' attention, possibly contributing to a 13 percent Apple stock rally today. I think you can expect the MacBook Pros to stay at the same price points, but a MacBook might drop a few hundred dollars. I wonder if my mom will buy one.
So that's what I think is going to happen. I have a Newsy shift tomorrow until 1 p.m. CST, which is about when the keynote will end. I will hopefully get a MacBook Pro by the end of the week, assuming they ship on the same timetables as the current bunch. It's more likely I'll have my computer next week, though, which is alright. I've waited this long. And that's another thing. While I am clearly Apple's bitch when it comes to this stupid MacBook Pro, if I have learned anything in the past month and the past year even, it's that this is only a thing, and things won't make you happy. In fact, I may come to rue this computer in the months and years to come, like I have come to hate my Dell. The computer could become broken or stolen, too, which would be very unfortunate. I mean, earlier this year I invested hundreds of dollars into a bike in an effort to bike commute to work and adopt a healthier lifestyle. The product of this was the theft of the bike and my need to replace it. While blatant consumerism has it's warm and fuzzy perks, we should keep this in perspective with the larger picture that these are only things and can easily be taken away. So if three months from now, after a nasty spill on my bike, I come to know intimately what the inside of my new MacBook Pro really looks like, I will try not to feel too bad. I mean, it won't be too bad giving the Dell another whirl, right? I lasted a month, what's another 2 years? *shutter* Anyways, so ends my MacBook Pro digression. I'll post once more when I have it and blogging can resume full steam. That means, hopefully, weekly Sunday blogs and somewhat daily morning editions will resume. And maybe some varied blogging, I've been a bit politics and technology heavy in the past few months.
item.excerpt:encoded: Let the blatant consumerism begin, depression be damned!

item.title: Sunday blog: The Apple tax
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It’s Sunday, so that means it’s time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it’s a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what’s on the skillet. OK, so it's been a while since I departed Mac hysteria. And It's also been a while since I've blogged about my most favorite issue, politics. So why am I wasting space on a Sunday on another Mac story? Well, I figure since I've beaten this dead horse over and over again with the corpse of my dead Dell, I might as well give the issue some perspective. OK, here it goes. So I bought a new MacBook Pro on Tuesday. It is a screamer, as Steve Jobs would say. As far as I can tell, it has the best specs of the year for a MacBook Pro, with a faster processor, state-of-the-art graphics and the maximum 4 GBs of RAM. Some things I wish I had? Well, I kind of wanted a 17-inch option, for admittedly no good reason. When it comes to computers, I am a resolution whore. My Dell, while it is a steaming pile, has the best resolution for a 2004 computer — 1400x1050 pixels. My new MacBook Pro is only 1400x900 pixels, mostly due to the fact that I am going from 4x3 to 16x9. I guess I'll get by on this. Anyways, before I go on a nerd rant for my new Apple, let's get back to the point: If you're looking to buy an Apple, you're going to pay more for it than you would a PC. Sure, you might argue that you're getting more for your money, but if you're switching to Mac, you're in store for some pain in the pocketbook. Don't believe me? Gizmodo had an interesting piece on the subject this week:
The Truth About the Apple Tax By matt buchanan Gizmodo ... In the case of Macs vs PCs, you could argue that customer support, the Leopard OS and design elements such as the new unibody construction and glass trackpads are what make up the Apple Tax. The only problem with this logic is that, when you compare Apple computers alone with no PCs in sight, the tax still swings wildly. ... HP's dv5t (pictured above) essentially matches for the high-end MacBook Pro's specs for $1,000 less, and you can add Blu-ray playback and a 400GB hard drive—features not available on the Pro—and still save more than $600. ... The real takeaway about the Apple Tax is that it's regressive—that is, lower-priced models get hit harder. It's like a tax break for the rich, cuz it almost always makes more sense to buy the higher-end product, especially given that build quality, customer support and warranties are all equal here. This is especially galling now, since being able to configure a cheaper model with what you really need—just the better graphics card, for instance—matters more than ever in this crappy ass economy.
Gizmodo has an interesting breakdown on how the new and old-gen MacBooks compare to some various PCs on the market now, so check it out. The Apple tax is alive and well, and as Steve Ballmer, CEO of Microsoft, points out, "I'm not saying that there are not some things that people like about Macs, apparently there are. But have you ever seen a cheap Mac? No." So why the heck did I just buy a Mac?! Well, for a lot of reasons. While Ballmer is right about the breadth of choices available for PCs, if you want a quality, long-lasting PC, you are left wanting for choices. There is no stand out Dell or HP product that polarizes consumers to it. Instead you're faced with multi-colored droves of cheap, plastic "pro" products that look more like squares on a roulette table. Sure, you can but a few grand on 36 red — or the HP dv5t, for example — but are you going to come out a winner in a year? What about three? Or five? The fact of the matter is Macs are built to high, exacting standards. As evidenced in the special MacBook documentary aired at Tuesday's press event, Apple had a winning design in the previous version of the aluminum MacBook Pro. However, the designers acknowledged its weaknesses and set out to improve upon them. The product is a new unibody construction technique, ala Seth Weintaub's brick, that aims to keep your MacBook insides protected for years and years. And they didn't just stop at the MacBook Pro. This design was used in the consumer-focused MacBook product, perhaps the closest relative to my Dell, which was a consumer laptop as well. In addition to constantly challenging the design and utility of their products, Apple provides unparalleled customer service and warranty support. When you are having problems and you give Apple a call, you won't have to worry about talking to an operator with a tenuous grasp of the English language. But how does this compare to PCs? Well, take my Dell for example. As I learned from the stellar disappointment that was my no name ProStar notebook I got in 2001, I got a 3 year warranty with my Dell computer. Like clockwork, the hard drive crashed after the first year (coincidentally just beyond the warranty that comes with the computer). The hard drive proceeded to crash two more times in the time that I had it (heck, it could be crashing again right now). In addition to this trouble, my Inspiron 5150 was subject to a class-action lawsuit over design flaws that led to motherboard issues. This has plagued me three times — the first time, I was ignorant of the issue and simply ordered a repair based on my warranty. The second time, after my warranty expired, I found out about the lawsuit and benefited from an extended warranty. The third time, well, just happened in the past month! So yah, I am paying more for a MacBook Pro. The notebook itself is more than double what I paid for my Dell. I can expect to put away over $700 on software just to migrate to Mac as well. But what will I gain? Well, hopefully, a notebook backed by a reputable company for the next 3 years (the term of my Apple warranty). After that, a sturdy notebook that will last upwards of 5 years, if I'm lucky. I want to be Carrie Bradshaw and her Powerbook G3. I want to be parading my MacBook Pro around while everyone else is pimping Mac float screens and iPhone Pros five years from now. So, yeah, if you are going to follow my path, be sure to acknowledge the peril of the Apple tax. If you believe it's worth it, then by all means, go for it. If not, there's still something to say for PCs, right? OK, blogging back to full steam this week. Two more weeks til election day! You know I'm going to hit the pols like crazy! Just wait until I'm finished moving into my MacBook Pro and I will be back :)
item.excerpt:encoded: Getting more for your wasteful spending

item.title: Obama breaks from campaign for ailing grandmother
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Sorry to say, but it appears the health of Obama's grandmother has taken a turn for the worse:
Obama to break off from campaign BBC News US Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama is to leave the campaign trail for two days to visit his sick grandmother in Hawaii. Madelyn Dunham, 85, who helped to raise Mr Obama, is said to be seriously ill. Mr Obama has spoken of their strong bond and has referred to her in some of his most powerful campaign speeches. BBC North America editor Justin Webb says despite Mr Obama's substantial lead over his rival, John McCain, his absence will make his staff nervous. The 47-year-old Illinois senator has the advantage in the polls with two weeks to go until election day on 4 November, but is not sufficiently far ahead to be confident of victory, says our correspondent.
So how will this play out in the media, especially in light of McCain's campaign departure weeks ago in the midst of the Wall Street bailout debate? It might be nothing, but check back. I'll post what I've found. Update: Over at HotAir.com, commentators are tying Obama's trip to see his grandmother to McCain's suspended campaign. "I question the timing," says TheBigOldDog. Mostly, though, commentators are including Dunham in their prayers.
item.excerpt:encoded: Family emergency

item.title: Kerry makes a joke, Republicans forget to laugh
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
So this silly story is making the rounds today. I mean, when I first heard about it, I thought maybe former Democratic presidential nominee John Kerry was just letting his mouth run again. But when I finally read the story, I actually laughed:
Kerry’s answer to the ‘boxers or briefs’ question: He goes commando and McCain would say ‘Depends’ By Jeremy P. Jacobs PolitickerMA.com CAMBRIDGE - U.S. Sen. John Kerry, the 2004 Democratic presidential nominee, had some choice words for the political press corps and, in particular, cable news Monday. ... "I don't know if any of you know what it's like. I do, obviously," he said. "I've been asked all of those brilliant questions that were repeated this year." "Barack got asked the famous boxers or briefs question," Kerry went on. "I was tempted to say commando." The senator said Obama successfully parried that question but that John McCain, the GOP nominee, had some problems. "Then they asked McCain and McCain said, ‘Depends,'" Kerry said to lots of laughter from the crowd.
It's unfortunate for John Kerry to find himself embroiled in another "joke" scandal like this. How can anyone forget about Kerry's notoriously bad sense of humor? In the days before the 2006 campaign, Kerry joked with Pasadena City College students on the issue of the Iraq War: "You know education, if you make the most of it, you study hard, you do your homework, and you make an effort to be smart, you can do well. If you don't, you get stuck in Iraq." Yeah, not funny...but Depends! That's hilarious, because of the obvious double entendre. I mean, the man was self-effacing in his joke, admitting that he'd answer "commando." Yeah, that's a scary though, much scarier than the very realistic fact of a man John McCain's age wearing Depends. So if you're a Republican and were "offended" by that joke (and you're not taking a cheap shot at John Kerry), lighten up and laugh a little! I would litter this entry with photos, but my move to Mac has temporarily neutered my Photoshop. My Parallels Vista is still getting up to speed and I am waiting for CS4 to hit the campus bookstore for cheap. I'll figure something out, just have to survive this week first!
item.excerpt:encoded: More scary: John McCain in diapers or John Kerry going commando?

item.title: McCain's electoral denial
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
News

  • According to a New York Times report today, the McCain campaign's hope for a comeback in this election rests on grabbing the electoral vote-rich state of Pennsylvania. Despite independent polls showing a double-digit advantage for Obama, McCain's surrogates claim the spread is only within seven or eight percent. While Pennsylvania is, according to McCain's logic, the Republicans' best hope of turning a blue state red, many red states are more realistically within grasp of the Democrats. Colorado, Nevada and Iowa have all begun to lean Democrat, giving McCain little hope of winning the White House. Will this trend reverse before Election Day?

Technology

  • Apple announced fourth quarter earnings Tuesday, reporting a $1.14 billion profit. Steve Jobs made a rare appearance during the earnings call, making some interesting comments related to some of Apple's ambitions toward netbooks, which are computers designed solely for surfing the Web. Jobs also made some glowing comments about the company's booming mobile phone business, which surpassed Research In Motion's own Blackberry, the once undisputed ruler of smart phones.

Politics

  • In case you haven't noticed, Barack Obama is kicking some new media butt as well as mopping up those electoral votes. This month saw the release of an Obama iPhone app, which connects supporters to information from the campaign. Social networking has also played a prominent role in Obama's campaign. But nothing compares to this: The Obama campaign has launched a Barack o' lantern initiative, urging supports to carve campaign messages into pumpkins this Halloween. Pictured below is my friend Braniff's pumpkin. I'm uncertain what role Turtle, the cat, played in the construction, but I assume he watches over the pumpkin in case it falls prey to McCain trick-or-treaters.
item.excerpt:encoded: Morning edition: Oct. 22, 2008

item.title: The humor of the Colin Powell endorsement
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
The big news the weekend, of course, was the poignant endorsement by Colin Powell of Barack Obama. Powell threw his support behind the Democrat, citing the divisive campaign tactics of Republicans. Powell was specifically moved to endorse Obama by the reaction he had to a photo taken by The New Yorker of a mother morning the loss of her son. The striking fact of the photo is that her son was a Muslim American, born in New Jersey. He gave his life at the age of 20 for his county. The Powell endorsement; Must see TV:
So what does McCain, an honorable, inclusive man, have to say about Powell's criticisms? Well, he's too busy laughing:
McCain dismisses Colin Powell's criticism CNN (CNN) — Sen. John McCain discounted former Secretary of State Colin Powell's criticism of his economic plans and scoffed at opponent Barack Obama's promises. "All I can do is laugh," the Republican presidential nominee said Wednesday in an exclusive interview with CNN's Wolf Blitzer in Manchester, New Hampshire. "We've been very consistent about cutting spending, cutting taxes, and the fundamentals of our economic message." His Democratic opponent, Sen. Barack Obama, has been "all over the place" with his economic proposals, including varying proposals on tax cuts, McCain said.
To see a man as principled as John McCain glide over the Powell endorsement with a chuckle is frankly surprising. I think the Republicans, once they absorb the weight of their coming loss, will find that shackling a man like McCain to the divisive politics of the past eight years was a huge mistake. The "maverick" McCain claims to be would have had no problem getting Powell to endorse his campaign. But thanks to the right wingers, who think the electorate can be moved by fear, demagoguery and lies, McCain has had to shelf his centrist ways in an attempt to win this election the old-fashioned way. Before sharing my predictions for the election (which have historically been notoriously inaccurate), I will blog about the honorable man, John McCain, who I believe will be a great casualty of this election. The fact is, McCain would be a great president. I truly regret that he fell prey to George W. Bush's dirty politics back in 2000. McCain v. Gore? No contest. We would be better off today with two terms of McCain than we have been with Bush (and, ironically, Republicans would have been better off as well). In the meantime, the right's flippant reaction to Powell's sober points is very telling. I know everyone is looking forward to Nov. 4, but I'm looking forward to Nov. 5. The reason being is that's when you're going to start hearing the mea culpas. That's when the Limbaugh's, the Hannity's and the McCain's will finally come forward and admit to the failures many of us see so plainly. Until that day, this campaign will continue to stink. Try not to stay downwind.
item.excerpt:encoded: So funny I forgot to laugh

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Like I mentioned earlier, this is my favorite day. On Nov. 5, that’s when all the finger pointing and recriminations emerge and finally politicians begin to be honest. The voters have spoken and, especially in this election, it’s not hard to understand what they are saying. [...]

item.title: Markets poised for great fall
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
News

  • After a brutal round of trading overseas Friday, U.S. markets are due for a wallop. Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial traded below 550 points, prompting automatic safeguards that stopped futures trading. On the bright side though, gas prices have fallen upward of $1 across the county, meaning that while your retirement accounts are hemorrhaging, you can at least make it to Hoboken for less than an arm and a leg. Lymph will do just fine. (Correction: It's not a wallop, instead a dive).

Politics

  • GOP vice-presidential nominee Sarah Palin threw the conservative, deport-them-now, wing of her party under the bus yesterday in an interview with Univision where she said she supported a direct path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in the U.S. today. This policy stance, dubbed "shamnesty" by some on the right, is likely to have a bright future in a potential McCain administration, whether conservatives like it or not. Lest we forget, maverick John McCain was key in brokering the compromise legislation that went down in flames in 2007. And we all know how I feel about that.

Entertainment

  • On Saturday Night Live's very successful Election Update Thursday night, Tina Fey's Sarah Palin and Will Ferrell's George W. Bush joined together for the first time to offer John McCain a very public (and embarassing) endorsement, to hilarious results! If you haven't seen Tina Fey in her hilarious, albeit (hopefully) brief return to Saturday Night Live, what rock have you been living under?! The clip is below.
item.excerpt:encoded: Morning edition: Oct. 24, 2008

item.title: McCain supporter cries crazed black man
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
So I have been avoiding blogging about this story like the plague, and it most centers around the fact that the woman in question, Ashley Todd, is just ugly. She's even uglier after what happened. So what happened to her? Well, she says that a 6-foot-4 black man attacked her at the ATM after he saw from her bumper sticker that she was a McCain/Palin supporter. The man supposedly straddled her body and carved the letter B into her face, at least temporarily branding her for Obama. Well, the man she described might as well have been Barack Obama himself for the amount of sense her cock and bull story amounted to. She's a faker!
Police: McCain volunteer made up robbery story By Joe Mandak The Associated Press PITTSBURGH — A McCain campaign volunteer made up a story of being robbed, pinned to the ground and having the letter "B" scratched on her face in a politically inspired attack, police said Friday. Ashley Todd, 20-year-old college student from College Station, Texas, admitted Friday that the story was false and was being charged with making a false report to police, said Maurita Bryant, the assistant chief of the police department's investigations division. Police doubted her story from the start, Bryant said. Todd, who is white, told police she was attacked by a 6-foot-4 black man Wednesday night. She now can't explain why she invented the story, Bryant said. Todd also told police she believes she cut the backward "B" onto her own cheek, but did not provide an explanation of how or why, Bryant said.
I mean, how did the man straddle the woman to produce a mirror-image of the letter B? And why would anyone want to carve anything into Ashley Todd, College Station, Texas, resident? At least she had the decency to confess. This whole charade might not be so surprising, but what might surprise you is who was among the first to refute the story. Sure, Drudge splashed the story all over his Web site, he's all about framing Obama supporters as sociopaths. But what did conservative commentator Michelle Malkin have to say about the incident?
Why that McCain volunteer’s “mutilation” story smells awfully weird Michelle Malkin Throughout my career, I’ve covered dozens of fake hate crimes — campus hate crime hoaxes, Muslim hate crime hoaxes, fake noose hangings, etc., etc., etc. Most were perpetrated by liberals, but there have been some shameful ones on our side of the aisle as well. I’ve reported on the great lengths that warped attention-seekers have gone to in perpetrating fake hate crimes, including beating themselves up, carving swastikas on their dorm room doors and walls, locking themselves in bathroom stalls, and burning down their own houses. Which is why I’m not jumping up and down with outrage over Drudge-promoted story of a McCain volunteer claiming to have been attacked by a black man whom she accused of carving a “B” in her face after spotting her McCain bumper sticker. She refused medical treatment after reporting the incident to police. Why on earth would she do that?
This is why Michelle Malkin is among my favorite bloggers. While I might not agree with her politically, and I find some of her points to be among the most flimsy (who's Dane and Associates?), she has demonstrated that she is a reasoned, consistant conservative voice, and I have a lot of respect for that. You see, some other red blogs jumped at the chance to frame this incident as a media hesitance to frame Obama supporters as violent toward McCain supporters, Malkin proves she's consistent in her appraisal of a stinky story. And you know what's even better? She leads with it all day. If you're hesitant of an Obama administration with a clear mandate to govern coupled with a super majority Democratic Congress (and you should be), then you can trust Michelle Malkin for at least a reasoned argument. Well, one from the far right side. Nobody's perfect.
item.excerpt:encoded: It was a black male, mid-20s...yeah, right

item.title: Politico copied my headline! (And sort of my idea)
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
OK, so maybe it was an easy headline for anyone to write and maybe the notion of a huge government bailout would be fodder for any Libertarian candidate, thus story worthy. But I am struck by the parallels:
Raising the Barr? By Daniel Libit Politico Sarah Palin's mod-librarian pair of Kazuo Kawasaki glasses have drawn the attention, but by far the most conspicuous frames of the 2008 presidential campaign are the thick spectacles of Bob Barr. As with so many of the distinctions claimed by the former Republican congressman-turned-Libertarian-presidential candidate, nobody cared. Alas, a neglected third-party run can evoke some serious self-degradation, as when Barr recently tried to siphon some of the attention showered on Joe the Plumber by giving himself the epithet “Bob the Builder.” "Sens. Obama and McCain are no friend to 'Joe the Plumber,'" Barr said in a press release. "But 'Bob the Builder' is. 'Bob the Builder' says that Joe should be able to keep the fruits of his labor, and shouldn't be responsible for the mistakes of other people…” Though Barr lacks the name recognition of Ralph Nader or Rep. Ron Paul, it seemed for a fleeting moment earlier this summer that he was positioned to grab a share of the spotlight, either from the residual interest of Paul supporters after the Texas Republican suspended his campaign, or by playing the role of Republican spoiler in his home state of Georgia. But no sooner were these potentialities gamed out by the press then Barr fell off the radar for months.
Sigh, I could only dream to work a story like this. I would have started it months ago. Just like the Politico has Ben Smith reporting on the Democrats and Jonathan Martin on the Republicans, I would take on the Barr. Seriously, why doesn't the media invest at least a little time into the Libertarians, or any other viable third-party option? Sure, the real reason why we don't hear much about Barr is because he can only hope to get 1 percent of the vote on Election Day, but the stage is set for a Libertarian surge. Here's a link to my entry last month: Bailout bust raises the Barr.
item.excerpt:encoded: Do I hear an echo in here?

item.title: Sunday blog: The fall of John McCain
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
It’s Sunday, so that means it’s time to highlight one of topics of the week. Whether it’s a bombshell in the world of politics, a barn burner in the realm of news or a shocker in mass media, I profile it here with the added gusto that only plate of french toast and a frothy glass of milk can provide. Check back next week to see what’s on the skillet. For my Sunday post this week, I want to talk about John McCain. I believe the great casualty of this election will the potential of a McCain presidency and the promise of a centrist president. As the campaigns race toward the finish, a mere nine days away, it's easy to forget that McCain was never what you'd expect from today's "conservative" Republican. McCain dared to be a moderate in a party where moderates aren't welcome:
He's not a conservative if he sides with the left. See, conservatism is what it is. It doesn't need to be moderated. It doesn't need to be redefined. It doesn't need to be upgraded. It's based on personal liberty: individual freedom, a small state that functions for the express purpose of defending and protecting the population. The minute you say that conservatism includes people who are pro-choice, you've destroyed conservatism because conservatism stands for "life, liberty, pursuit of happiness."
Far be it from me to dispute the inclusiveness of conservatism with Rush Limbaugh, but John McCain was the conservative moderate. He was an experienced statesman who practiced bipartisanship and was never one to take the credit. One of the actions John McCain has taken as senator that I most admire is his inclusion among the gang of 14 in the spring of 2005, which averted the elimination of the Senate filibuster and allowed Bush's conservative jurists to be confirmed by the Senate. Many people are ignorant of this, it's quite boring to think about really, but McCain bravely faced the ire of his party to defend the minority and their right to have a voice in the Senate, despite their status and agenda. Think about it: The Republicans have just triumphed in a heated campaign against Democrats, earning Bush's precious political capital and cementing their majorities in Congress. Eager to deliver their conservative agenda, Republicans had only to reach 60 votes to mold the federal government however they wish. But Democrats, with only 45 senators, could still gum up the works by use of the filibuster. Senate leader Bill Frist had to power to end this ritual, restoring the Senate to ending debate on a simple majority, a number they could easily muster. Facing this, John McCain, along with six other Republicans and seven Democrats, made a pact. If these 14 senators felt the filibuster was warranted and the jurist at hand truly was too radical for the bench, these senators would vote to prevent Frist's nuclear option for the filibuster. On the other side, if the senators felt a filibuster would be disruptive to the Senate's business and unwarranted, they would vote to close debate, thus ending any filibuster.
Republicans don't want you to know about this, or at least they don't want you to remember. McCain was the co-chair of a group of senators that derailed conservative hopes of influencing government in ways they could only dream. And these Republicans also fail to see the great irony of their skewering of McCain on his actions: It was just two years after this that Republicans lost control of the Senate and suddenly found great use for the filibuster. Had they succeeded in eliminating it, many laws they fought to squash would have easily passed (the immigration compromise, for example). There are many other instances where McCain has reached across the aisle to pass important legislation, often times breaking with the brass of his own party. McCain lobbied to ban torture in U.S. interrogation techniques at a time where the administration wanted nothing in law on the subject. McCain embraced on of the most liberal senators, Russ Feingold, in crafting legislation that could close holes on soft money contributions in political campaigns. This point has put him directly against Republicans, who hoped the law would be stuck by the Supreme Court (which it wasn't). They says it curtails free speech, but what it really does is bundles up Republican donors and deters quid-pro-quo governance (well, it at least closes one oft-used avenue for that). I could go on and on, but the point I am trying to make is that there's a reason conservatives like Hannity, Limbaugh and Coulter all screamed bloody murder when McCain clinched the Republican nomination: He's a moderate, and Republicans have no room for moderates. So why is the McCain that is 9 days from losing this election not the moderate we have seen through 26 years in the Senate? Here's something the New York Times mentioned in their endorsement of Barack Obama:
Mr. McCain, whom we chose as the best Republican nominee in the primaries, has spent the last coins of his reputation for principle and sound judgment to placate the limitless demands and narrow vision of the far-right wing. His righteous fury at being driven out of the 2000 primaries on a racist tide aimed at his adopted daughter has been replaced by a zealous embrace of those same win-at-all-costs tactics and tacticians.
And in the Washington Post just today:
A year ago, the Arizona senator's team made a crucial strategic decision. McCain would run on his (impressive) personal biography. On policy, he'd hew mostly to conservative orthodoxy, with a few deviations -- most notably, his support for legalization for illegal immigrants. But this strategy wasn't yielding results in the general election. So in August, McCain tried a bold new gambit: He would reach out to independents and women with an exciting and unexpected vice presidential choice. That didn't work out so well either. Gov. Sarah Palin connected with neither independents nor women. She did, however, ignite the Republican base, which has come to support her passionately. And so, in this last month, the McCain campaign has Palinized itself to make the most of its last asset. To fire up the Republican base, the McCain team has hit at Barack Obama as an alien, a radical and a socialist. Sure enough, the base has responded. After months and months of wan enthusiasm among Republicans, these last weeks have at last energized the core of the party. But there's a downside: The very same campaign strategy that has belatedly mobilized the Republican core has alienated and offended the great national middle, which was the only place where the 2008 election could have been won.
McCain's campaign has become more like the Republican Party we love to loathe and McCain himself has been seemingly relegated to the master suite of the Straight Talk Express. By playing on the delusion that conservative governance, which got us into this financial meltdown, is what this nation thirsts for, McCain has thrown his most formidable card out of the deck: his true maverick credibility. This was not McCain's idea, I'm sure. The Republican Party, with victories in 1994, 2000, 2002 and 2004 still fresh in their minds, could not initiate in this election cycle the kind of transformation that will eventually return them to the White House. They chose to hold onto their failed politics and duck the accountability they should own for Bush's failed leadership. The cost for them will be losing this election, but our collective cost will be losing the opportunity to deliver a principled, deserving leader to the White House: John McCain. It is my view that the Republican Party would have been better served by a McCain victory in 2000 than it has been by a two-term Bush presidency. I probably wouldn't have voted for McCain in 2000 and I certainly won't vote for him in 2008, but as an American who has lived with leaders he did not vote for, I believe McCain would have been a better choice. And I promise you, the true strength of John McCain will be apparent to everyone on Nov. 5 when the pundits and Republicans finally acknowledge the weight of the John McCain defeat. Next Sunday: Election predictions.
item.excerpt:encoded: And the loss of true leadership for all Americans

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Nick’s Blog » Is there something to the press-initiated McCain drain?
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] narratives about McCain have remained unchallenged by the media. I mean, come on, did you read my Sunday blog for McCain? I totally don’t hate the guy and a lot of left-leaning journalists don’t [...]

item.title: DRUDGE REPORT: Increasingly irrelevant
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
My good friend Natalie and I have a list. It's a list of people who are increasingly irrelevant. These people seem to think that they continue to be the prime movers in the universe, but in reality they are so irrelevant it's sad. Well, I'm adding DRUDGE REPORT to that list today for failing to give the biggest story of the day its due: It might be hard to notice from the DRUDGE REPORT, but a seven-count guilty verdict of Ted Stevens, former president pro tempore of the Senate and the longest-serving Republican in the Senate, was released this afternoon. The verdict, which will be vigorously challenged by Stevens, is likely to result in his re-election loss to Democrat Mark Begich, contributing to the progressive revolution that is likely to wash over this county just eight days from now. Anyways, here's what CNN has to say:
Jury finds Stevens guilty on corruption charges CNN WASHINGTON (CNN) — A jury found U.S. Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska guilty Monday of all seven counts in his federal corruption trial. The jury found Stevens guilty of "knowingly and willfully" scheming to conceal on Senate disclosure forms more than $250,000 in home renovations and other gifts from an Alaska-based oil industry contractor. Stevens faces a maximum sentence of up to to 35 years in prison -- five years for each of the seven counts. Legal experts note the judge has the discretion to give Stevens as little as no jail time and probation when he is sentenced. He sat expressionless as the seven verdicts were read out at the end of his trial, less than a day after the jury began deliberations from scratch because of a change in jurors.
Senator Ted Stevens is an entertaining figure in the Senate who will be sorely missed by the likes of The Daily Show and The Colbert Report, who have made many jokes at the expense of Stevens. The photo here is humorous to myself because, in 2005, Stevens made a concerted push to have Congress open up the Alaska National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling. Expecting victory, Stevens wore one of his many colorful ties. In this case, the Incredible Hulk (It's hard to see, but I think the superhuman is crushing some caribou). Well, moderate Republicans and Democrats were successful in preventing Stevens' agenda from passing, much to his chagrin. Oh, I love politics. Of course, if you have been paying any attention to the DRUDGE REPORT lately, you would notice that all last week, Drudge tried (and failed) to frame the presidential race as tightening and moving in the direction of John McCain. Now facing the likely scenario of an Obama victory and a Democratic sweep, Drudge is trying desperately to get this socialism story to stick. It's hard to say he's really being successful, but it's quite sad watching him try. I am totally one for embracing balance in the news, but sometimes I wish Drudge could acknowledge that the Republicans are in a tailspin and another guilty verdict swept to the sidelines isn't going to go unnoticed. I mean, the man might go to prison! He's the second longest-serving senator in the country! You can give him a 100-point headline for at least a few hours. At least CNN had it up for a few minutes before handing off their top spot to the Jennifer Hudson story (very sad). Oh, and in case you're curious, here's how the "increasingly irrelevant" list stands today:
  1. owls
  2. Jimmy Carter
  3. Hal Sparks
  4. Ron Paul
  5. DRUDGE REPORT
One note: Two former co-workers also populate this list, but I won't repeat their names here. You'll just have to read this list on my fridge to learn their identities! Muah ha ha ha! One more note: As for the news Drudge seems to think is the most pertinent today, he has led all day with some boring story hitting the dead horse that is Obama's "socialist tax plan," which it's not. If you want to know more about the differences between the Obama tax plan and the McCain plan, Parade had a great graph (reproduced below) that makes some interesting points about the key differences:
item.excerpt:encoded: Coming in at number seven on the list...

item.title: File this under stupid: In Virginia, Democrats vote on Nov. 5
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
This is utterly ridiculous:
Phony flier says Virginians vote on different days By Julian Walker The Virginian-Pilot A phony State Board of Elections flier advising Republicans to vote on Nov. 4 and Democrats on Nov. 5 is being circulated in several Hampton Roads localities, according to state election officials. In fact, Election Day for voters of all political stripes remains Nov. 4. The somewhat official-looking flier – it features the State Board logo and the state seal — is dated Oct. 24 and indicates that “an emergency session of the General Assembly adopted the . . . emergency (voting) regulations to ease the load on local electorial (sic) precincts and ensure a fair electorial (sic) process" The four-paragraph flier concludes by apologizing “for any inconvenience this may cause but (we) felt this was the only way to ensure fairness to the complete electorial (sic) process.” However, no emergency action has been taken by the General Assembly, which isn’t in session, and furthermore, doesn’t have the authority to change the date of a federal election. State Board of Election officials today said they are aware of the flier, but disavowed any connection to it.
For one thing, the damn phony flyer spelled "electorial" wrong like twice. WTF?! Can you believe that (what I can only assume to be) Republicans are resorting to tactics like this to suppress the vote in this election? This is not the transformation that will return Republicans to the White House, this more resembles a corrupt despot digging his nails into the threshold as he's escorted from the building. Get real.
item.excerpt:encoded: Electorial incompetence

item.title: Obama is coming to Columbia!
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Wow, this is amazing. How great it is to live in a swing state!
Obama to hold rally in Columbia on Thursday night By Missourian staff COLUMBIA — Sen. Barack Obama, the Democratic presidential nominee, will be in Columbia on Thursday night. The Change We Need rally begins at 9:30 p.m. Thursday in the Mel Carnahan Quadrangle at MU. The visit will be the second time this month that Obama has been in Missouri. On Oct. 18, he spoke to a crowd of more than 100,000 people in St. Louis, which was the largest crowd of his campaign so far, and in Kansas City later that day to an estimated crowd of 80,000. Republican nominee Sen. John McCain made a stop in Columbia on Oct. 20.
I think I'm going to go. How often to you get the opportunity to see the future president of the United States? It's going to suck being engulfed in an Obama crowd, but I have a day before another 4804 ball-busting pitch meeting, so I might as well do something fun before I surrender another week to convergence reporting. Maybe I'll post photos!
item.excerpt:encoded: The change we need

item.title: Is there something to the press-initiated McCain drain?
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
This week, I was happy to discover a surprisingly relevant addition to my mass media seminar readings: a very timely Pew Research Center study of the 2008 election narrative, comparing McCain's performance to Obama's. The study reveals, not surprisingly, that McCain has endured more negative coverage than Obama:
Winning the media campaign: How the press reported the 2008 Presidential General Election The media coverage of the race for president has not so much cast Barack Obama in a favorable light as it has portrayed John McCain in a substantially negative one, according to a new study of the media since the two national political conventions ended. Press treatment of Obama has been somewhat more positive than negative, but not markedly so. But coverage of McCain has been heavily unfavorable — and has become more so over time. In the six weeks following the conventions through the final debate, unfavorable stories about McCain outweighed favorable ones by a factor of more than three to one—the most unfavorable of all four candidates — according to the study by the Pew Research Center’s Project for Excellence in Journalism.
Undeniably, McCain's performance in the media campaign has been very poor, but does this automatically equate to the media's supposed liberal bias? Some interesting points in the study:
  • The media's negative coverage originated mostly by the negative correlations McCain absorbed as his poll numbers dived and as the media continued its tradition of covering the horse race aspect of the campaign. Therefore, the argument that the media was harsher is somewhat mitigated by the fact that the media was fixated on the dwindling opinions the public harbored, which were reflected in the falling poll numbers for McCain.
  • Sarah Palin had a bit of a honeymoon with the press when she was initially introduced, but fell prey to the negative light shined by the press. This has been both good and bad for Palin (but mostly bad). Palin suffered after her much discussed interview with Katie Couric, recovered a bit with an adequate performance at the vice presidential debate, but "cratered" shortly thereafter (what a horrible word, I mean, seriously). Palin's advantage was clearly the volume of coverage she's received in relation to her counterpart, Joe Biden, who is referred to as "the invisible man" in this study.
  • The top campaign storyline uncovered in the study was the economy and financial crisis, sucking up 18.4 percent of all coverage. Coverage of the four debates followed at 16.6 percent and, interestingly enough, Palin-related stories followed after that. Despite receiving the lion's share of negative attention, McCain still bogarded the media's attention with his vice-presidential pick.
So does all this equal blatant media bias? It's hard to think that Republicans would interpret it any other way, but I submit that it isn't media bias. The fact of the matter is, the press is going to cover the race and is going to try to interpret who is "winning." It's a safe place to play in because poll numbers don't have any bias, and the fact of the matter is McCain hasn't shown a significant statistical advantage over Obama in months. "He's Picard, you're Troi. Get used to the feeling, Betazoid!" Politico also waxes on about the subject, and just to insert a bit of "Republican fairness" here, I'll use Drudge's headline:
Don't blame us for the bias, McCain campaign sucks... By John F. Harris and Jim Vandehei Politico ... Responsible editors would be foolish not to ask themselves the bias question, especially in the closing days of an election. But, having asked it, our sincere answer is that of the factors driving coverage of this election — and making it less enjoyable for McCain to read his daily clip file than for Obama — ideological favoritism ranks virtually nil. The main reason is that for most journalists, professional obligations trump personal preferences. Most political reporters (investigative journalists tend to have a different psychological makeup) are temperamentally inclined to see multiple sides of a story, and being detached from their own opinions comes relatively easy. Reporters obsess about personalities and process, about whose staff are jerks or whether they seem like decent folks, about who has a great stump speech or is funnier in person than they come off in public, about whether Michigan is in play or off the table. This is the flip side of the fact of how much we care about the horse race — we don’t care that much about our own opinions of which candidate would do more for world peace or tax cuts.
This is a point I can personally attest to. If I were a biased partisan hack, I could totally make this blog a left wing nuthouse instead of the moderate blog I at least try to mold it into. I don't know if you have noticed (maybe I should enable my WordPress tag cloud), but I blog way more about McCain than I do about Obama. While I'm not voting for McCain, he facinates me more and more as this campaign comes to a close. I would much rather cover the McCain campaign than to Obama campaign because it stimulates me as a journalist. There are some real questions there. To what extent is the media treating him unfairly? What campaign narratives about McCain have remained unchallenged by the media. I mean, come on, did you read my Sunday blog for McCain? I totally don't hate the guy and a lot of left-leaning journalists don't either. The Politico story also points out that it's not like these "mainstream outlets" (if you can call Politico that) aren't trying: "A couple weeks back, Politico managing editor Bill Nichols sent out a note to the campaign team urging people to cough up more story ideas that took a skeptical look at the campaign tactics and policy proposals of the Democrat, who is likely to be president three months from now." So how can the media correct the imbalance exposed by this study? I'll try to answer that as the week goes on. First question, just of the top of my head: What is socialism and is Obama really advocating it?
item.excerpt:encoded: Bias? What blatant, exposed liberal bias?

item.title: DRUDGE desperation growing
item.dc:creator: Nick
item.content:encoded:
Politics

  • According to the DRUDGE REPORT, polls are tightening as the election edges closer and closer. Is this a reflection of reality or has Drudge finally fallen off the deep end? If he's going to take the Rasmussen and Gallup polls seriously, perhaps he should look at some of the state-by-state polls, which reflect the stark reality that McCain is trailing by double digits in must-win states. At the end of the day, this race will be decided by the electoral college, not the popular vote. So is the race tightening? Not bloodly likely. If anything, Drudge's grasp on reality has loosened quite a bit.

News

  • While markets soared yesterday and are expected to rally again today, there's no denying the credit crunch isn't over. In fact, according to a New York Times report, the downward spiral threatens to strike even closer to consumers: Straight to the plastic hearts of their pocketbooks. Credit card companies are preparing for what may amount to a year and a half of billion-dollar loses, resulting from defaulting payments and massive write-offs.
  • The deteriorating economy is forcing newspaper to take drastic measures. The Christian Science Monitor, an oddball already of sorts (in that subscribers are mailed the 5-day print edition), is shifting to an online-only journalism model, a choice many newspapers will begin to make in the next five year, they contend. Over at my old journalism playground, Gannett, employees are likely to see deeper staff cuts amounting to a 10 percent slash in payroll. The issue was covered extensively yesterday over at Gannett Blog, much to the chagrin of management. The secret memo released exclusively to publishers leaked to Gannett Blog hours after it was sent, forcing the company to dispute inconsistencies to provide damage control for the PR blunder.
item.excerpt:encoded: Morning edition: Oct. 29, 2008
